output: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Siebeb for the work he has done, because his report contains many of the concerns expressed in this report.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers of the European Communities has adopted a resolution on the situation in the former Yugoslavia.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report which I was rapporteur on in the Committee on Agriculture in favour of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role played by farmers in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors aggravating the prices of raw materials, an aspect in which the times that are passing also seem to me very important to point out, so that we take into account not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Committee on the Environment, on the other hand, included the idea of creating a European drought observatory, an action which is also mentioned in the report of the Committee on Agriculture and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete facts.

The text to be put to the vote tomorrow, however, does not include a proposal made by the Committee on Agriculture to study the launch of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund which would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the creation of this fund, an idea which I will again propose to Parliament when the communication which the Commission intends to publish on adaptation to climate change arrives in the coming months.

It seems to me that after the Solidarity Fund was set up, which was created in its day to alleviate the losses caused by climate disasters, it is time to think of an instrument that acts a priori and is intended to finance preventive measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.
Atlético de Madrid, the fans and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case goes beyond the particular, because these federal bodies aggravate the sanctions on those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this law of the plumbing, is incompatible with the law, with the European institutions from which we have to react.

And we will end up doing so because these medieval gentlemen, arbitrary hangmen and knife-wielders, must be brought into line with the respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.

Mr President, Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and the action of serious organised crime is also a global phenomenon and therefore the means must be proportionate and must be fought effectively.

I have taken good note of the answers you have given to the questions which were timely. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that this is a delicate subject, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable to set up a globalised and harmonised response.
For some, terrorism takes them a little further away, they're more concerned about individual guarantees.
I am concerned about the individual and the collective, and it is absolutely necessary that we start where we can.
If we're going to start with air transport, where the companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let us demand guarantees, let us see what the scope is, let us start with international transport relations and, look, we will have to go through the interior, because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
Ask the United States and ask the others, that's the way it is, and that's the way we'll have to ask it.
Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I think it is a positive proposal and it will help us to reduce the administrative burden if necessary.
Now, as the speakers who have preceded me have said, this Parliament has an obligation to bring to the table what are very generous and very altruistic proposals on the part of the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are twenty-seven countries with different legal systems and with very different languages, which requires that in each of these countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gossez has pointed out right now and as previous speakers have pointed out, it is important that the recognition of these national specialties does not lead to an increase in costs, that the rates are uniform and that governments eventually assume that additional cost.
But there is also a subject that arises, and that is the subject of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.
In the 27 countries, very different languages are usually spoken between them, and even in some countries, such as the Commissioner's, different languages are spoken, and we live with this.
And from a legal point of view, we also encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
In the Legal Affairs Committee, for example, the Legal Affairs Committee has proposed amendments on the authentication of the documents, together with the authentication of the translation.
At the moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in different countries of the European Union, which should complement this report.
In short, I think the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The rapporteur has done a magnificent job and I think we have all made an effort to make a legislative proposal that can be recognised throughout the Union, guaranteeing the
rights and starting from the foundations of the reality of a Union that is being built, that has different national arrangements and that has different levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr President, a large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting decisions and prior agreements to be adopted by the Council of Agriculture Ministers of the Union between today and tomorrow on this cheque from the European Parliament.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion with any impact on the negotiations being held by the Union's Agriculture Ministers.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not.
Not because of a lack of resources within the CAP's spending ceiling, but because of an absolute absence of political will to provide the Community budget with this necessary pillar development.
They want to liberalize the markets.
Of course, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both inside and outside the Union.

At the moment, the European Union is gambling with the future of many farmers and ranchers, and I would especially like to refer to the fragile sectors such as sheep, cattle or tobacco, whose survival in many productive areas will depend on this check.

Some producers, such as sheep farmers, no longer ask for help, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done their homework and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

The abandonment of production is therefore the only way out that we leave to many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers by leaps and bounds.
Parliament should give a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I would like to thank the President of the Committee on Agriculture, Mr Parris, for the efforts he has made to ensure that Parliament is listened to and that the Council and the Commission have not acted in such a clear and ostensible way as they have done so far.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Capula Santos, on his magnificent work.
I think you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I think the important thing at this stage of the debate is to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are needed, as well as maintaining specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Commissioner, the same solutions are not valid for all sectors.
And it must be remembered that we have sectors that are going through real difficulties.
The common agricultural policy does not have to be the problem, but the solution, and for that we need a first strong pillar.
We believe and are committed to rural development, but we do not believe that the Commission's proposed modulation is the solution.
It is not a question of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme should be simplified, that the market instruments should be reviewed.
But that doesn't mean dismantling them.
If we do it right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013, otherwise we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan that is eagerly awaited by the fruit and vegetable sector, not only because of the difficulties it is facing, but also because of the worrying decline in consumption.
I believe that we are facing a public health promotion plan. I believe that it should be a European plan and I also advocate full Community funding.

I do not agree that parents should be able to participate in the co-financing, because it will be the same as always: parents who can contribute money, their children in schools will consume fruits and vegetables and those who will not be excluded from the programme.
I believe that it must be a plan financed by the Community in order for its distribution to be homogeneous.
That is why I also want to emphasize that the emphasis should be on educational measures.

It is not just a question of a student eating an apple, but of knowing what kind of apple he is eating, knowing its nutritional properties and understanding the beneficial effects that this fruit has on his health and development.
Of course, these must be products of the highest quality, with priority given, if possible, to seasonal fruits, and when possible I defend the Community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I think that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, will be noticed immediately, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

But I also think it is very important for the horticultural sector, a productive sector which constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage, because thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I think it's worth betting and investing in this plan to distribute fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I think the budget is a little short because, again, I am in favour of full Community financing for such an ambitious plan as this.
Mr President, I ask you not to include these first words, please, in the time machine, because, in my opinion, they are not enough.
My first words are to add to the message of condolence expressed by this House to Mrs Klamt and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now I'm really starting.

I congratulate the rapporteurs because with these two proposals we are taking a qualifying step towards a common immigration policy and we are entering the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach we are defending.
The general framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal emigrants should be extended to the largest number of workers.
That is why the Socialists call for no category of workers to be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
It opens a single door to 27 labour markets.
Now, this is not the only door through which highly qualified workers should enter.
That is why we hope, Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present its proposals on the other categories of work.
Ladies and gentlemen, we must fight against brain drain.
This blue card must not become a passport that favors a bloodbath of vital human resources in developing countries.
That is why, as the Socialist Group, we want every qualified professional who comes to Europe to be paid for the training of a new professional in the country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talents from outside the Union but also for ours.
In 2007, almost 300 highly qualified Europeans went to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything possible to keep them in the European house.
Madam Vice-President, do you think that the proximity or distance of candidates to voters has something to do with the degree of participation in the European elections?
Do you agree that a State of 45 million inhabitants has only one electoral constituency for the elections to the European Parliament?
What can the Commission do to ensure that the states with the largest population have constituencies closer to the citizens?
I'm sorry, but I didn't hear the Vice President answer my questions.
Madam President, you have given me a great deal of information on the subject you were raising and I thank you for that detailed information.
I think the Commission's new stage is important and, above all, the Bamako project, a centre of the European Union for immigration.

I know that it has just opened, which is probably very soon, but the question I ask the Commission is in the event that this Bamako Bali project on immigration produces good results, does the Commission think it is possible to extend this experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I appreciate the answer on behalf of Mr Iánez, but I must say, Commissioner, to Mr Michel, that his actions, his words and his gestures are very necessary in direct and direct contact.
I really want the Cuban democratic opposition to comply with the Council's priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favour of freedom.
Mr President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I would like to express my Group's strongest condemnation of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, in the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the way in which this atrocious murder was committed, we already know, a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery and that five men, if you can call them men, hurry to stone them and even prevent someone from trying to save them, in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, combined with the acts of piracy that this year on the coasts of Somalia have reached the level of almost 100 ships hijacked, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
You cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit barbarism.
We must therefore restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia to regain control of the entire country and to establish a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions have we been presented with such a clear situation and that it imposes obligations on us.
I do not think we can stand idly by in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in this situation.
I do not know how this can be done, but of course I believe that it must be done and that we must intervene quickly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments which have been tabled at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this will be the beginning of a greater concern on the part of the European Union about this type of humanitarian issues and the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit barbarities in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who have preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a directive by Parliament and the Council.
It is a question of recognising that armaments and ammunition are also within the internal market, although, of course, with a number of limitations.
These are not ordinary goods, they are not candy, they are not entertainment objects, but they are objects that require precise control.
Of course, there are limitations in the Treaty itself, Article 30 and Article 296, which confer on States important responsibilities in this area.
And the fact that we have a common market does not prevent States from being obliged to comply with safety rules and from having the right to apply them when their own safety is at stake.

The work done in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the committees of opinion, which have collaborated with them in accordance with the Council, under the expert direction of the rapporteur, Mrs Ruiz, has been very positive.
I think the text we are presenting today is a fairly balanced text.

Basically, although there seem to be many amendments on paper, today we are limited to one amendment, namely Amendment No 63, which is the one that captures the spirit of commitment, and in that amendment you can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow the functioning of this whole market.
Mr. Toubon has pointed out that this is in relation to other international texts.

For example, the adoption this month of the Oslo Convention on the Prohibition of Cluster Munitions, the Convention on the Limitation of Antipersonnel Mines and a number of international agreements and even European Union rules aimed at limiting the use of weapons.

I believe that our model is not the model of the free movement of arms at any time, but of a regulated market controlled by the States and also controlled from now on by the institutions of the European Union itself.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal came from the Commission more than a year ago with really very ambitious objectives.
And at this time there have been financial convulsions in the world that seemed to be going to shipwreck these measures, but finally a balanced agreement has been reached.
It does not satisfy almost anyone, 100 per cent, but it is a good agreement which maintains the final objectives but which gives companies more equity, the means to achieve them.

That is why we must thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Doyle, the rapporteurs of the other political groups and the French Presidency in particular, because their work has led to a good result for everyone.

I am confident that in the near future circumstances will allow us to be much more ambitious and that there will be other countries that will also join this crusade against climate change that we so want to carry out in Europe.

Mr President, Commissioner, this was a good proposal, as the Commission came out with it, not only because of the reductions in sulphur but also because of its new Article 7b, which required suppliers to provide a
gradual reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and because it solved the old problem of steam pressure for gasoline mixtures with bialkohol in countries like mine in hot summers.
This is precisely what did not pass the vote in the Committee on the Environment, and this worried many of us.
Today we have an agreement on the table which smooths the application of Article 7 and which resumes the waiver of the steam pressure, of course making it harder to access the exception.
As in the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone 100%, but it is nevertheless acceptable to everyone.

I would like to thank Mrs Corbyn for her excellent work, for the receptivity she has had in solving problems, and also Mr Turmes and, of course, the French Presidency, which has also shown great effectiveness here.
In fact, as the report says, according to estimates for 2007, Zimbabwe has a population of 12 million, almost half of whom are starving.

The average life expectancy is 36 years and only 40 percent of the country's teachers are working and only a third of the students attend classes, so Mugabe is not only killing the present, he is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights is also on the agenda.
Zimbabwe's human rights defenders have been systematically the target of arbitrary arrests, arrests and torture.
Legislation introduced by the Government severely restricts freedom of expression, assembly, movement and assembly.
I would like to quote several of them, since the Government has introduced increasingly repressive rules which have been used against these human rights activists.

For example, the Law on Access to Information and Privacy, used by the Government to effectively silence journalists, the Law on Public Order and Security, which has severely restricted freedom of assembly and hundreds of

Human rights defenders, including workers in independent media, have been arbitrarily detained, as has the Private Voluntary Organisations Act, re-established in 2002 by the Government and allegedly used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my mother tongue, Basque, which is not official in this House, Mugabe means unlimited, a good motto for this character.

The dictator of that African country is not just another one in the long list of dictators that we unfortunately have on this planet, but I dare not say that he occupies one of the top ten positions of dictators.
I think that in the EU we have to do the impossible to get this character to leave and end his days sitting in front of a human rights court.
We wish Zimbabwe a happy 2009 without Mugabe.
We have a motion for a resolution on Nicaragua in which we have to take different aspects.
Firstly, there are allegations of fraud in at least two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this is hampering the November 9 election result.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned with solving some of the problems that eliminate human rights in Latin America.
In particular, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, the provision of drinking water and the lack of ownership of indigenous lands.
So, when we examine the case, we have to distinguish perfectly between the two aspects.

On the one hand, we have to stimulate human rights and we have to defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other hand, we have to encourage the Government of Nicaragua to continue in its role of helping the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we have to ensure that the opposition can exercise its function, we have to oppose fraud, but we also have to defend the actions of the NGOs.
But, nevertheless, we must have a balanced result.
The Socialist Group has tabled several proposals for oral amendments, trying to bring the final text into line, so that it is more balanced with regard to the allegations of
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

In short, we want to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of placing the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult situation to continue to fulfil its function of supporting the most needy.

Mr President, I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the situation in Nicaragua caused by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some of the fundamental freedoms and against democracy.

It is not necessary to remember here and now Zoilamerica, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez or so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr Ortega asked and democratically obtained from the Nicaraguans what he called a new opportunity.
Today we already know why he wanted her.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism and corruption have taken root in the institutions of government, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9 elections.

Very serious decisions had previously been taken, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of some opposition parties, threats and intimidation of members of civil society, journalists and the media.
President Ortega called the governments of the European Union "flies flying over the dirt" and the external aid Nicaragua received "crumbs".
He soon realized that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

When we are about to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an Association Agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua must know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression and democracy in general is a condition that we do not give up because we believe that the people of Nicaragua in particular benefit from it.
Until last November 9th, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been called into question from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud and fraud having been made.

There have been demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, with the result of numerous wounded and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been suffering.
Two political parties could not stand in local elections, which is unacceptable because it violates the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.
On the other hand, we have received direct testimony from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us of the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

On the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought up to 17 social movement organisations before the courts, on the persecution of independent journalists and even on the delegation of the European Commission.

For all this, we want to raise our voice and make a call, firstly, to the political parties to condemn the acts of violence committed by their supporters, and secondly, to the Government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

Citizens' rights, respect for freedom of expression, an end to the ban on marches and the possibility for all NGOs to receive aid from international cooperation, not just from Venezuela for pro-government associations.
Likewise, to abolish the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases of danger to the life of the mother.

Finally, we also want to ask the Commission that the negotiations on the Central American Association Agreement in the European Union remind Nicaragua that it must respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to the fact that from Europe we continue to provide our assistance for the development and welfare of the Nicaraguan people, who we hope will have the best possible future.
Madam President, I am going to refer to the Breyer report.
And I have to say that European farmers are fully aware that the use of phytosanitary products must pay particular attention to human health and also to the protection of the environment.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this Regulation may have in the future.
And there are assessments of its potential impact, which point out that, due to the limited future availability of phytosanitary products, it will be very difficult to
the control of pests and diseases affecting the cultivation of large quantities of food, in particular all Mediterranean products, and also the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the trilogue has been the result of a hard negotiation and I cannot help but acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

However, it must be borne in mind that the temporary definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have at their disposal a sufficient amount of active substances to combat effectively and safely any plant disease or plague, bearing in mind that often the danger is not in the product but in the misuse of it.
For all this, the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group supports the proposals calling for an impact assessment and will vote in favour of the amendments.
Mr Stardy, which I myself have signed, relating to endocrine disruptors and those which favour the availability of phytosanitary products in case of emergency.

In addition, if this Regulation is adopted in the terms of the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and an increase in prices, which will lead us to importing those same foods that we do not produce, treated with the products we are consuming.
Mr President, Mr Capato, your report is a report full of goodwill. The most obvious proof is that it did not deserve any amendment in its handling during the Committee on the Liberties of the People.
Was it you who introduced 18 amendments to your own report?
And it is these amendments that have introduced a plus of radicalism to this report, let us put it in general terms, which raises very serious doubts in my mind.
I would like to raise in four different ways the amendments which you have tabled, which you have tabled yourself, in a report which received the support of all the groups at the outset.
Some impossible, I'll substitute some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr Capa, you are asking for things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, as long as the Treaty of Lisbon does not enter into force, it will be impossible to harmonise the regulations of the various committees.
Commissioner Wallström has just said something similar to this. Or do you ask, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency? We are late, there is no time limit.
So you're asking for things that are impossible.
In addition, he asks for some others that are inadvisable.
For example, you call for transparency in the meetings of the political groups.
Not only that.
Because privacy is needed, privacy is a political good.
If I want to disagree with my party, maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not within parties, where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
So I can't follow him on that.
There are some other appreciations you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that 90 percent of legislative activity is by committee.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr Capato.
And, moreover, climatology carries implicitly some standards of transparency in itself.

If what we are going to do now is to make more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to pursue, which is transparency, which is something that is very close to simplicity.
And finally, before the President draws my attention to the fact that I am already wasting my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very soft and very attractive for public opinion to say transparency in the activity of Members, that it is known that they come to the plenary.
You know, Mr. Capato.
Or that they go to the committees, you know, if there's a record of all of them, they're accessible to all citizens.
or the debts they charge, you know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

So I understand that it is very difficult to deal with public opinion and that it is very adorned to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is making things look the way they are, and when you contribute to making things not look the way they are, Mr Caputo, then we are not contributing transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.
We see the situation in Gaza with horror, pain and shame, but also with the commitment to defend peace and those who suffer the most and to maintain dignity and hope.
Horror at the repeated scene of murdered children and women torn apart in their infinite suffering after the bombings of the ghetto into which Gaza has become.
The same horror that Picasso painted in his Guernica, our Guernica, razed by the Junkers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
Solidarity pain with so many victims of so much suffering.
And shame on the inability of all of us, of our states, of the European Union and of the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression that we denounce.
Shame and indignation for so much lies, for so much ambiguity and for so much rhetoric.
It is a shame because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and demanding forcefulness and coherence.
Therefore, history will hold many accountable as accomplices to crime, at least by omission.
Because it is better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door of hope open, the European Union will have to support the late Security Council resolution, but there will be...

We will have to make sure that Rajatabla is fulfilled, as Rajatabla will have to fulfill our Association Treaty with Israel, which provides for its suspension in the face of behaviour such as that which is taking place.
By the way, Hamas is also responsible for the media blockade, which I haven't heard anyone denounce until now.

We must say clearly and emphatically to Israel that it must stop killing, allow the wounded to be healed and the injured to be fed, and that its attitude against international law must have consequences for its relations with Europe.
I would like to greet the few young European cooperators who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, in particular Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of this Europe of ours, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we have seen in recent times, the textile sector is experiencing a major crisis which has led to numerous firms closing down, relocations and unemployment, facts which are concentrated precisely in regions specialised in this activity.

In the face of this current economic crisis, the European Commission should act quickly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I think it is necessary to help the workers in the textile and clothing sector with social measures, with plans for companies which are undergoing restructuring and which are in serious trouble at the moment.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and recycling of the textile sector.
This is particularly true of small and mediumsized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and which suffer the most from the effects of market liberalisation.
On the other hand, it is necessary to restore the system of control of imports from abroad and, in particular, their volume from China.
It is not at all a question of promoting trade barriers.

It is a question of compensating for the negative effects of such an important transformation, and we must not forget that the European Union is the world's second largest exporter of textile and clothing products.

This makes it necessary to ensure better conditions of access to the markets of third countries, which are essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.
All this, of course, always guaranteeing fair competition on the basis of the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this sense, the publication of the correct information to the consumer, for example with the regulation on the indication of the medicinal product, which, as we know, has not been implemented, would be of great use, since
This would, among other things, involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and protection requirements for consumers as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr Romeva, the Spanish Government, don't worry, will cooperate, as it has always done.
I would remind you that in this matter the Spanish Foreign Minister, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Committee of Inquiry and answered all the questions, including his own.

We in this House have been denouncing for some time the inhuman and degrading torture and treatment that was being committed at the Guantánamo military base in the name of the fight against international terrorism.
That is why we applaud Obama's decision to suspend the trials for four months and his goal of permanently closing the prison within a year.
Now, although the responsibility lies with the American Government, the Union cannot look the other way and must offer its cooperation in order to achieve the closure of the detention centre.
We must also appreciate the possibility of welcoming those prisoners who come from countries where respect for human rights is not guaranteed, if the United States so requests.

Then we will have to give a common European response, in which the Spanish Government will participate, in respecting the international legal framework and in analysing case by case the legal situation of each citizen, of each detainee, the origin and the detention and their situation.

Mr President, there are several cases in the EU of languages belonging to historic European peoples which, because they are not constituted in the State, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque Basque language, which is not a minority language but an official language, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which is administratively part of the Spanish State.

But the same thing does not happen, and it is not taken as something personal, Commissioner, with the Basque Country of the North, attached to the French State, whose President, before the UN Assembly, claims that denying respect for national identities and languages is to feed humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then neither Basque, nor Corsican, nor Breton, nor Occitan have the slightest official consideration, nor do they have support to respect or promote their use.

That is why I call on the Fundamental Rights Agency in Delhi to work to ensure that the rights of the mother tongue of any European people are not violated within the Member States, that its inhabitants are not discriminated against and that they are all considered official within their respective territories.
Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your support, for all the languages of Europe.

Madam President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this directive we are once again demonstrating our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The approach of this directive is clear to fight against the mafia, to punish unscrupulous employers and to protect exploited immigrants who do not have any kind of social protection.
We want the unfair wages of misery for immigrants to disappear and to disperse the average wages, especially in sectors such as construction, the countryside, domestic service or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, since there are many interests created and a lot of money moving in the submerged economy.
It is precisely in difficult times that it is more important than ever to manage migration flows intelligently, with generosity but with responsibility.
It would be easy to fall into the temptation not to try to cut back on the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave some eight million irregular immigrants in a situation of helplessness, with working conditions close to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions are needed in the most serious cases, which have a deterrent effect for entrepreneurs.
We will thus be able to reduce the underground economy and cut the migration incentive that generates the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal way.
That is why we want to continue with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Barrot, to present as soon as possible the new blue cards for the other categories of work.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana, I would first of all like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work, and as the shadow rapporteur for the PESCO report, I will refer to the
I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Saris Volsky on the outcome of his work and on the collaboration he has offered from the other groups to achieve a consensus.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to have the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the House itself can also show cohesion in assessing and promoting the major priorities of the common foreign and security policy.

The commitment of our group, the Socialist Group, has gone in a double direction: on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues which, for us, are crucial, transversally, to the whole of foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of

On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the PESCO with regard to how they originally appeared in the text, if they did appear, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.

In this way, for example, we have advocated greater clarification of the relations between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the Eastern dimension, which has recently been defined.
We have advocated greater diversification and greater relevance of relations with Africa, a continent which we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and often not even so.

With regard to Latin America, we have wanted the current processes of association agreements to be reflected, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As far as the Mediterranean is concerned, we have opposed a reductionist approach which speaks only of security, to include, on the other hand, all the rich political, economic and socio-cultural wealth contained in the Barcelona process.

As far as the amendments for the plenary are concerned, our group has not tabled any, believing that this would somehow strengthen the balance achieved with the commitments and we will therefore oppose most of the amendments in order not to weaken the commitment reached in the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Mr President, the Venezuelan referendum has been crowned with a triumph of the yes, elegantly recognized by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunity in the campaign and that the bureaucracy has had the overwhelming support of the entire apparatus of the State, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela to find its democratic, pluralistic and free path.
In this sense, we criticize the decision of the Venezuelan Government to expel a Spanish MEP and, much more, the way in which such an expulsion was carried out, but we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements on their visits to third countries which violate the current local legislation and, even less, that they insult a Head of State, no matter how critical he may be.
With these attitudes we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr President, I have just arrived from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral power as a member of an international electoral support group for the referendum on 15 December.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with a positive overall assessment of the process in terms of its organisation, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote and security at all its stages.

On the statements made by Mr Herrero to a Venezuelan television, I would point out that they were intended to discredit the ongoing electoral process, to cast serious accusations against the democratic institutions of that country, and to cast doubt on the internal policy of a sovereign country.
Our Parliament should not promote any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the honourable Member to explain to this House an action which affects all of us.
The Committee on Budgets believes that the clear allocation of each of the budgetary instruments is of the utmost importance.
The most realistic option therefore seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions different from public development aid in the countries covered by the Regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, the proposal for funding from the Committee on Development does not seem appropriate, since this money does not exist.
There is a credit for 2009, but not for beyond.
In any event, since the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007 financial framework, it is appropriate to
It is important to recall the importance of the interim review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the various headings.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission will probably have other things to worry about than this report.
In short, what we are doing is merely responding to a report by the Commission, a report on the application of Regulation No 1260 of the European Parliament.
Council of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the competent authorities of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in an area which is really not Community, but an intergovernmental area, in which the Council, through the Regulation, has tried to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I think there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

In other words, certain measures have been envisaged, for example the issuing of practical guidelines, the use of electronic media, etc., but I recognise that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.
I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to achieve because of the enormous difficulty of this form of intergovernmental cooperation.

We are asking the judicial authorities to collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities that handle 22 different languages, with very different legal systems, and we are trying to get results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do so.
The ideal would be to have material means.
For example, what could the Commission do to equip the judicial authorities, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements such as a videoconference system?
Video conferencing may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, in particular the European judicial network.
We would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this kind of communication.
On the other hand, whatever the training of judges, it is fundamental.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own either.
But the Commission can stimulate the development of this type of training courses in Community law and in the knowledge of the different legal systems.
And then there's a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can you communicate, let's say a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge, with two so different languages.
It cannot be claimed that judges, in addition to having to deal with their own law, which is already quite complex in itself, are obliged to have knowledge of this type of law.
What can we do from a practical point of view to facilitate the interpretation and translation task for the judges?
Translation: What can we do to help you?
to present this report, to show no rigor or hardness towards the Commission.
I think the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of what we have here, from a Commissioner who is interested in this subject, is what the Commission thinks can be done to be able to give more

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a regulation on the common organization of the market in wine is a compromise which does not meet the objectives of the regulation.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I remember that when I arrived in the European Parliament in 1999 we suffered a great maritime accident, that of the ship Erika, near the French coast, which gave rise to a first block of legislative proposals aimed at tackling and avoiding accidents.
We thought we had already conjured up the danger, but shortly afterwards the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the blow from another accident, even greater than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, in the Committee on Transport we have been working on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the too many resistances we find in shipowners, oil companies, classification societies and also in certain Member States which rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

In these ten years we have adopted different directives and regulations, some of which we have had to review again because, as a result of the cuts prompted by the Council, they were not effective in their first draft.

We have approved the rules for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Fund for Major Oil Disasters, ports of refuge and now we have reviewed and approved the responsibility of passenger shipping companies for the investigation of the

maritime accidents, the Community system for the monitoring and information of maritime traffic, control by the Port State and, finally, the Regulation and Directive on ship inspection and recognition organisations.
And all this is good and desirable that it can come into force and be applied by all the Member States in the shortest possible time.
But I feel satisfied.
But when the legislature is over, I leave Parliament and I regret that I have not succeeded in making it compulsory to introduce control systems which exist.
They're patented to know when and how much waste from sentinels and fuel tanks has been illegally dumped into the sea by a particular ship.
That is to say, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by the maritime authorities every time a ship arrives in port.

I think we owe the marine environment better attention and more severe procedures to curb the pollution we produce and that, if we do not, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I hope that they will not have to spend another ten years to control illegal sea dumping more effectively and efficiently.

Mr President, the revision of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance which concerns and concerns us all, especially the peripheral countries which we feel are victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to tackle the internalisation of the external costs of road transport by attributing three new costs: atmospheric pollution, acoustic pollution and congestion.

Although the principles inspiring the proposal, who uses pay and who pollutes pay, are reasonable, the proposed solution is by no means discriminatory against a sector which has been suffering for months from the disastrous effects of the economic crisis.
Demonizing the transport of goods by road, even if it was not the goal, has turned out to be the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is inappropriate and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, would be the death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies employing thousands of people.

There are people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that the products reach their final consumer, a consumer who will see how their products are priced by the application of these tariffs.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable and environmentally friendly transport system, without neglecting the road, because today it is the only way to get everywhere.
Modal change is still a dream, far from reality.
Trans-European networks, sea highways and cross-border connections are still, in some cases, projects and not reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, much less for joy.

Mr President, on 15 July 2008 the European Commission adopted a communication to the Council and Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations on 13 October recognised Mexico as a strategic partner, pending Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us remember that already at the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the European Union - Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we said that a
A strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We note the good moment of relations between the two parties and the positive balance of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen cooperation in political, economic and cooperation matters to the fullest extent possible in the face of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country of Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equality, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development and respect for human rights.
We advocate closer cooperation in the fight against organised crime, terrorism and drug trafficking on the basis of the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
We will therefore support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Partnership, which will be submitted to Parliament this morning.
I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs on the microcredit report because they have done a great job.
They have undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations set out here will allow us to be the basis for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the micro-credit sector.
It has been a success in many developing countries, even in some European countries, both as a mechanism of economic activity and as an instrument for improving social inclusion and job creation.
But it had not been transferred to the sector or to the Community context, and I think it is an opportunity to do so, especially in the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
It is a priority in this respect to strengthen the initiatives that are being taken here, but more steps must be taken.
We need to increase the funds available for this micro-credit support structure.
We must make it easier for people and companies who do not have access to loans to be available, and in this respect I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of the
the European Microfinance Loan Guarantee as an instrument that can facilitate that access and that has been included in the report.
And I conclude by thinking that this will undoubtedly lay the foundations for us to be able to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the micro-credit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are talking about a budget, I understand that we must be prepared for the continuation of aid to coal, an essential indigenous source of energy, to be negotiated next year.

And I say this with due urgency because, in an improper way, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed himself to have an opinion in the opposite direction, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
We will have to continue to support my country's coal after 2012, and I want it to be on the agenda.
Limit yourself, ladies and gentlemen, to complying with the current plan and then, from 2012, with the instrument that we start negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr Böckland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the Ship Recycling Convention which is to be held in May.
That is why I would like to congratulate Mr Blokhan not only on the question but also on the resolution he has prepared.

Madam President, in the People's Party we are in favour of the fight against the bad practices and methods that are being used to dismantle ships and we therefore support Mr Brokland's motion for a resolution, but there are some points that concern us.
The first is paragraph 3, which he has also pointed out, which says that ships as a whole must be considered as hazardous waste and, consequently, must be within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment to this section because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted, but it must be the future international agreement on shipwreck that defines the details of its application.
The motion for a resolution also calls for a financing mechanism based on compulsory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It really seems to us a little hasty to talk at this moment about compulsory contributions when it has not yet been decided within the WTO what system will be adopted for this financing, and it seems to me that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter either.
Finally, in paragraph 15, the Commission is urged to make it clear that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
We also believe that it is the Commission's competence to decide this, which must also be decided at an international convention.

The important thing is to ensure consistency on the future Convention on Ship Recycling and the Basel Convention on cross-border control of hazardous waste and its removal, all this taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing I would like to do is to congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we have a great coincidence in this programme, and to congratulate all of us, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a programme like this with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, at this time of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned

We are not only concerned about the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those which support those most in need, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution programme must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy, as we agree with the Commission here, in addition to the fact that European agriculture has a marked social character, because it is an instrument that works, because it is needed now more than ever and because it must continue to work.

Mr President, like the rapporteur, we in the Socialist Group are opposed to this programme being confidential between the European Union and the Member States, because that would mean discrimination between States according to their wealth, and it could happen that the programme could not be implemented in the countries most in need.

It is not understood that now, when more is needed, the Commission wants to save Community money on the most social side of the CAP, especially in view of the fact that there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full Community funding is fundamental for us.
We need to ensure that this programme reaches all countries and, above all, the most needy.
The 43 million potential beneficiaries of this programme call for greater effort and, in no case, savings in budgetary expenditure.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizens of all the Member States that the programme must cover the entire route of the food distributed.

That is why the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, has tabled an amendment to ensure that all expenditure derived from distribution, including transport, storage and administrative expenditure, is covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food must be preferably Community and of quality.
It is the position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programmes which we recently discussed in this House, such as the plan for the distribution of fruit in schools.
Nothing more and thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission will take account of this Parliament's position when it votes and, above all, that it will put the European Union's plan into action as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and for the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of large areas has brought these risks to the fore, requiring a new global regulation to protect the Arctic, similar to that already in place for Antarctica, even taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is needed between all the parties involved, including the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the full sustainability of all types of human activities and multilaterally regulate navigation on the new sea routes that become accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these moments of difficulty and uncertainty, we must take this spirit and this harmony to a higher level in order to prevent the States of the area or other international actors from engaging in geostrategic fights, forgetting what should be the common objective of preserving a great shared heritage.
Mr President, unlike the two speakers who have just spoken before me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it comes to looking for a smarter model of doing business, what we're really talking about is ending intellectual property.
Because you can only do business if there's a law in place.
We already have a law established at national level.
The Commission, under the leadership of Mr McCreevy, has taken a courageous initiative, a positive initiative, and I think that the House must approve the commitment we have made.

We have achieved this in the Committee on Legal Affairs and Citizens' Rights thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crawley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Mrs McGuinness and Mr Tuppence.
I think it's a magnificent directive, it's a directive that's going to boost the creation of intellectual property.
In addition, this Directive includes a number of recommendations on the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval by this House of this report and I hope that the Council will align itself with the lines of the Council, the Commission and Parliament will serve to ensure that in the next legislature the

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to Parliament and make progress in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression we have of European parliamentarians and, in short, of European citizens is that we have a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At the moment, as tax requirements are being strengthened in each of the Member States, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a kind of vicious circle, under which the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us to the Commission, but the reality is that the citizens who live in this Europe that we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relations as a result of the heavy tax burden that the lack of tax harmonization can entail.
Can the Council do anything to get us out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that I am not the head of the group, that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And as a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration we European Members have with the application of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to get involved with the Commission, and I think we are asking the Commission for an impossible mission, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

The Commission has only a few officials at the headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has some possibilities for action, but at the moment, moreover, it tends to limit the budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all application of Community law is based on the action of the national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here, in this respect, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission, and I think that in Mrs Frassoni's report there are some points which can be useful in achieving this application.
I am referring to those relating to the correlation of directives, the cooperation of national parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr President, two years ago, on a mission led by my colleague, my group member Marianne, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and to be present in this court and to be aware of the immense work that this court was doing, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court of Sierra Leone, as has already been said here, has certainly set a precedent.

It is a precedent because, as the resolution rightly points out, it is the first international court to be funded by voluntary contributions, it is the first court to be set up in the country where the alleged crimes took place and it is also the first court, as has already been pointed out, in which a former Prime Minister has been tried.

For all this, not only because it is a precedent, but because it is a reference for other courts that have been created at its peak, such as Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be adopted, on which we have been working together with the Court for several months.
Two years ago we passed a resolution to support its financing. Two years ago the Court was going through a difficult period in which it was left without
We have to thank the European Commission here, too, for coming out in support, let us say, financially, of this Court.

Now we are asking for two things in particular: firstly, that the convicted persons serve their sentences. What is at stake is no longer the functioning of the Court, which will end next year, but the legacy that this Court will leave us. Secondly, obviously, all this must be accompanied by greater funding.
In short, the Special Court of Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, when we entered the court, we saw a written motto that said that without justice there is no peace.
And that is precisely why we have the moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, that the legacy of this Court should remain permanent in history.

Mr President, I would like to thank you very briefly, ladies and gentlemen, at this time, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for demonstrating, as you did in the third package, the need for a European budget.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens at work has been rejected by the Council.
I think we should congratulate ourselves.
I am certainly grateful for the close cooperation between the opinion rapporteurs in both the Committee on the Environment and the Committee on the Environment.

I thank and reiterate the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs and, in short, I believe that tomorrow we will adopt an agreement at first reading on such an important rule which will undoubtedly complete the work of the

The third maritime package is a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in all three institutions and justifies, once again, the codecision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favour of all citizens of the European Union.
I have one minute left before I want to answer the Commissioner, who knows of my friendship and affection for her and, indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr Orbán.
But the Commissioner has not said a word about the Ombudsman's recommendation.
The Ombudsman, who knows all the arguments put forward by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation which the Commission seems to ignore in all its extremes.

I don't even want Mrs Cuneva to answer me, because obviously she doesn't have the data, but all the data she gave me is in line with what we knew and what the Ombudsman also knows and she doesn't tell us if it's actually true.

In spite of all this, and since the Ombudsman, who knows this, recommends that the rule be changed, it does not tell us whether the Commission will assume what the Ombudsman asks and what Parliament recommends, in accordance with what the Ombudsman has asked.

Mr President, I believe that the proposals for a regulation which the Commission has submitted to us are important and necessary, and on the other hand it was also important and necessary that the Commission should be consulted on them.

I would like to ask the European Parliament to insist on the principles which have been insisted on by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, both Mr Swieske and Mr Deprez, and that is the principle of Community competence.

It is a matter of Community competence, in which, for practical reasons, it is appropriate to maintain certain competences of the States, but, as Mr Barrot has said, limited in terms of scope and time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, the Commission nor Parliament have the power to waive those Community competences.

Having said that, this is an exceptional procedure and I believe that the amendments which we have discussed and which we have tabled and which I believe will be adopted by Parliament tomorrow will allow this package of measures to be adopted at first reading.

But I also hope that the Commission will, in the future, and on the basis of this, be able to make progress in the development of a genuine European private law which is increasingly needed, as Mr Sógor pointed out in his last speech.
We are talking about the problems that affect people most directly and, as we are in a position to solve these problems of the people, people will realize that the European Union has a function.

In short, Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr De Vries and Mr Lesbianska, and to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to cooperate with us on this issue.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and I have asked to intervene on this plan because I witnessed the so-called expulsion, but in the end it was the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

And I also found that it is common in Venezuela for political persecution, the abuse of power by the Chavista regime, the intimidation of the opponent, the threat, the contempt for the dignity of people and the misuse of justice, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chavez is the drop that has eaten the glass and that has given rise to this resolution, but there are thousands of cases as bloody as yours that are cited in the resolution and others that are not cited.

As is the case with Igio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caraqueño neighborhood of Petare, well known for its dangerousness and, in addition, because he voted for a mayor who was not of the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied with the help of others, specifically Citibank, managed to start his own business, the Bank of Caracas, and then he lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he is illegally imprisoned in a prison in Caracas, after two years of being detained without any due process.
His only crime is to be part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nilson Moreno, student leader of the University of the Andes, elected several times to the university council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 federal election, the current Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of murder, in a degree of frustration, lascivious acts, violent and all that, despite having been exonerated of such accusations.

Situations like yours are everyday life in this country, where the persecution of the adversary, in order to exclude him from political life and discourage dissent, has become a fact of everyday life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to the Venezuelan democracy, despite the difficulties I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be deposed at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
That is why the resolution adopted by this Parliament cannot be another resolution which serves to highlight the great concern caused by the misfortunes of others.
Forest fires are caused by one or another cause, but no one can deny that they feed on climate change.

And, irrespective of the responsibilities that may exist in some States or in some autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, at its disposal.
Neither the victims, nor the damage suffered, nor the need for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budgetary shortcomings.
We must prioritize and we must act, and to act in this case is to modify strategies, mobilize resources, increase them and coordinate preventive policies in an optimal way, demanding the arrival of

In any case, responsibilities to the States that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem of some states in southern Europe and that climate change does not affect only some states, it affects everyone and is a common cause.
That is why one of the main tasks facing this Parliament in the near future must be to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the next Copenhagen Summit.

And they are tough to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are obviously at the base of the fires, of their causes, and these, in turn, are the causes of more climate change.
Therefore, the adoption of this resolution is now the challenge of this Parliament, for sure.
But let that challenge of the Commission be met if, indeed, Commissioner, you want to prevent the south of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the floor.

Mr Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and respect for a long time, since you were ruler of a country which is very close to us and very dear to us, namely Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that now you have me absolutely surprised.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have shown contempt for the group in which I am present, the group of non-members, by not giving us a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, because of the fragility of your political project, because of the poverty of your political proposals in the document on political guidelines for the next Commission.
