I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
I was surprised in this sense that issues such as energy, which, throughout your mandate, have been well treated, now that you offer us your concerns for the next

Madam President, Commissioner, you ended your words by telling us that there was a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by telling us that you had already taken all the measures and that the matter was being resolved.
Look, rectifying is wise.
And that's a Spanish saying that could very well apply to the case we're dealing with today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months one of the most serious crises in its history and, despite this, because it does not want to give you its arm to twist, or the European Commission or some of the governments - including mine, it seems - the Spanish Government, which refuse to back down on the decisions of the CAP health check.
These decisions were taken without taking into account the fragility of this sector and in a very different market context than that which arose after the closure of that commitment.
It gives the impression that the Member States either did not want or could not see the storm approaching at that time.
The reform was unsuccessful in a short time because of the great turnaround that the market has made, a turnaround which shows that the sector is at the mercy of the volatility of prices.

That large producers such as France and Germany, countries which achieved in absolute terms in that agreement the greatest increase in their national production quotas, that those countries are now the ones calling for a review of the cheque decisions, is very thought-provoking.

In my view, the Member States were wrong and should have listened more carefully to the voices among which I find myself, who were asking us to postpone until 2011 any kind of final decision on the future of the sector.
It's a pity they didn't listen to us.
If they hear you, do it now.
Mr President, this Parliament is the palace of chimeras, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their vote, with their vote so strong, give us the courage and the strength to continue to prosper and to build a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the fathers of Europe, for whose work we are all here.

Mr President, having overcome the uneasiness generated by the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my view, to think about the treatment that will be given in the future to the nationalist attitudes which so hamper the construction of Europe.
My idea is that these numbness can't be free.
With a cold head, it is time to think about the possible measures to be taken in the coming days and years.
This modest Member of Parliament wants a President of the Council in the future who is a man, or rather a woman, convinced of European federalism, who manages the
I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has adopted a number of resolutions on the situation in the former Yugoslavia.
Commissioner, that is to say, on behalf of the Commission, I would have no choice but to add amen, but I had already prepared an intervention on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras breaks two decades without a hit in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest, as is the case now in Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and dumb in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation, in line with the position unanimously adopted by the OAU with the support of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto President Michelette has violated the agreements reached recently, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return to the presidency of the outgoing President, Mr Celaya.

In the present circumstances, the election of a new President in the elections scheduled for 29 November is fraught with illegitimacy of origin and its results cannot and should not be recognised by the international community.
The European Parliament would make a serious mistake if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, because that would be interpreted as a guarantee of the coup d'état.
This Parliament has been characterised by being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.
As Bachelard Havel said this morning, there can be no two weights or two measures.
We are all democrats here and, therefore, freedom fighters, and so, whether we are talking about Cuba, China, North Korea or now Honduras, our speech must be firm in the face of liberty killers.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing dictators, only libertarians and repressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change and with this a very dangerous precedent will have been created and the doctrine of the good, temporary and not too cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr President, I would like to congratulate the members of the Denby Committee and its chairman, Mr Leinen, on the work they have done to ensure that we can have a resolution like the one we have and that we must adopt it with a thoroughness.
We cannot be satisfied with talking about sectoral agreements, because talking about a retail agreement is already admitting part of the failure.
We have to go and approve this resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
One more obvious one is to avoid climate change with concrete proposals for reducing emissions and with a commitment to financing and aspiring to a binding agreement, not to mention retail.

And two latent aspirations: one, to start working sooner rather than later to have a common energy policy, as we had in those days, a common agricultural policy, because it was necessary, and, of course, that is also included, to regain the confidence of the citizens in the policy and in the politicians of which we are not left in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the President-in-Office of the Council to remain optimistic, to put pressure and to negotiate everything possible to bring others to this success.

I do not know whether the rulers of this multipolar world want to be brought to justice by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a Member of Parliament and I believe all the representatives of the peoples, cannot be brought to justice by history for not being able, in Copenhagen, to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity to prevent climate change.

Mr President, there is no doubt today that the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Programme we will continue to make progress in this space of freedom, justice and security which is so necessary.

In my view, this struggle is based on mutual trust between the Member States, but it is now and with the possibilities offered to us by the Treaty of Lisbon to harmonise national legislation in the direction of the non-prescription of terrorist offences, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament, no one else, will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening and can continue to happen, with the resulting damage to the victims of terrorism, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter for the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defence of memory.
Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate Mrs McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the needs of international food supply.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the EU budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be, and in recent decades it has been seen that without the CAP food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared with other sectors of the economy capable of prospering in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union in order to be able to take his business forward, and the Union in turn needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but not disappear.

To this end, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, as well as to re-establish a policy of management of agricultural markets which would bring greater stability in prices, which would benefit not only farmers but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practice to promote balanced relations between the different agents of the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of trade margins.
In addition, an information policy for the European consumer is needed, which emphasises the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union regulations on the matter of
environment, food security and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with productions from third countries where very low standards are applied to imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union than to supply the markets of their own countries for a sincere question of profitability, with the backing of the WTO negotiations.
Mr President, according to a report by the United Nations, in 2009 some 270 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union be based primarily on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to watch indifferently this theatre, this spectacle of sexual exploitation, which is unfolding before our eyes.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request that the assistance to the victims be unconditional, more severe and more severe, as Mr Barrot has just told us.

Having said that, I would like to ask the President and the Council to use all the European legislation that is in their hands, both the existing and the future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European order for the protection of victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument to combat these crimes.

And I hope for a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency, so that this order offers the victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society will give a real and concrete response to this very serious problem of human trafficking and that we will not be left alone in saying good words.
We owe it truly to all the victims.
Mr Zapatero, for a Spaniard, as is my case, it is an honour to welcome you here as President-in-Office of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges in this period, and of course we cannot disappoint the expectations created.
Let the citizens see that our renewed institutions are an instrument capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But the answer, Your Honor, is that it's shared by us.

That for the Spanish People's Party this is a matter of state and that we are going to be behind His Lordship in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that for Spain it is important.
It is an ambitious programme and it is a programme which, I hope, will be full of content.
I would like people to see in that album of the Spanish Presidency, which I am sure will be colorful and varied, that they see in each event a milestone on real problems that affect them.
The crisis is hitting economies and unemployment seems like a fifth horse of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to recognize that 20 percent unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not disqualify you.
What I think is that it forces you to produce among all a solution or a problem, really, that we have to solve among all.
That's a real problem.
Time doesn't allow me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead of it, that I believe, I have the security of the capabilities of Spain as a nation and that I want to believe, and I am sure, that you will be up to the task in our country.

We cannot disappoint these expectations in this hour of Europe, on the other hand, the globalised world - and it has referred to this intelligently - is producing new centres of power, and the European Union needs to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of being irrelevant.
Finally, Mr President, we Spaniards do not accept that anyone should deny us the ability to make proposals.
We have that legitimacy.
What we also have to have is the humility to accept those advice of Don Quixote that Sancho gave him when he recommended humility in the dream of the government of the Barataría Island.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly parity government and the courageous way in which it has brought gender equality and respect for the other to the European national agenda.
Mr President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious programme of action, of course, against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender Violence is a leading proposal which European women support and applaud.
Mr President, on behalf of the Portuguese Socialists, I wish you good luck.
Can you count on our solidarity?
Solidarity, women with the Zapatero.
Mr President, on a subject as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to act.
We should anticipate this, but we don't.
And, unfortunately, we are moving forward with attacks such as the failed Detroit bombing, which today forces us to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding on body scanners at airports is a responsibility we cannot avoid, ladies and gentlemen.
We can't keep waiting because the terrorists don't wait.
The Commission must therefore as soon as possible guarantee that the dignity and privacy of people will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
With this in mind, we must take decisions for the whole of the European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights are being violated, I will tell you that there is no higher right than the right to live, and those of us who love freedom above all else need to live safely in order to feel truly free.
Mr President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with firmness and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In this strong Europe, the expression "improving coordination" is likely to be dispensed with, since it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and strictly refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as there is no progress towards European financial integration and no issuance of Eurobonds.

In any case, the European institutions can already take concrete action - I do not insist on the wording of coordination - and there is, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and
I wanted to say that I did not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly introduced law on abortion in Spain.

What concerns me is human life, and I am concerned above all and I am here to defend women whose lives are in danger because of gender-based violence and to offer them a space in which they can live freely and safely.

The resolution of this Parliament of 2 February 2006 recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and that they take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.

The Stockholm Programme, adopted in this House, established a space of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens and in it the fight against gender-based violence was considered a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency to promote, during its mandate, a European order for the protection of victims of gender-based violence to ensure that the victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender-based violence should also have no borders, and Member States should strive to harmonise their legislation so that the fight against violence against women is more effective.

I would like to ask the Commission and the Council, therefore, to do everything they can to ensure that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission are able to take the necessary steps to ensure that the European Parliament and the Council are able to take the necessary steps.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position on this matter?

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban revolution, which so much echo and illusion meant for the peoples of the world, for the most pomegranate of international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the impiety with political and conscientious prisoners, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco Moribundo, with the mistreatment of political prisoners, which he also considered common, his own obsessive contempt for the exiles.
Castro ends up as Franco and all the enemies of freedom when they come to power.
But we must save lives and show solidarity with those who are struggling and suffering.
It is our duty as Europeans to be committed to democracy, freedom and human rights.
Madam President, President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with the libertarians.
We will never again allow a person who fought for his rights and those of all to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else without our strong and firm voice rising to demand his salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old citizen of Albanian descent who only asked for better prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And in those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, beaten by his prisoners, in the midst of, it must be remembered, a thick silence of the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Ladies and gentlemen, the resolution we are presenting today, which we are debating today and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, calls for the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It once again advocates a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not, for the time being, get into a matter that divides us as to whether or not the common position should be maintained.
Let us now focus on the issue of saving lives and human rights.
And we are talking about a period of serene reflection in which we seek places of encounter on the issues of future policy with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that six political groups are present here expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the subject of human rights.

Never again to say that the European democratic right is bending to the orders of Yankee imperialism, but never again to say that the Social Democrats are complacent or complicit in the communist dictatorship.
Simply because both claims are false and the victims of the libertarians, wherever they are, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Salafranca, who has negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs Weber of the Alliance of the Dead and Liberals Group, and Mr von der Vring.

I would like to thank Mr Roméva, on behalf of the Green Group, Mr Kasutnik, the Conservatives and the Reformists, and other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

Finally, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and the President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in bringing forward this resolution which we are debating today.
History will absolve me. It was the famous allegation of a young lawyer who made his people vibrate.
History absolves him, in effect, of his rebellion against tyranny and then against the blockade.
But with the same emphatic condemnation, this Parliament, which represents the greatest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that
The people of Cuba suffer from the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, the contempt towards their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this resolution, Members of all ideologies, we stand with the Cubans who are fighting.
The brutal repression they suffer must be avoided by all possible means, even by overcoming the paralyzing so-called common position.
I pay tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on love, emptiness, asphyxiation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Calm down, my friends.
We're leaving now.
This week was International Women's Day.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, violence against women can be stopped.

Mr President, we are talking about violence in Mexico today and it seems normal to me to recognize that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or the police to murder.
Unfortunately, so far, the responses of the Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and that is why it is rightly said that there is almost absolute impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat femicide - a harsh but correct word - when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico in the last four years were sentenced only 11 of the criminals who killed almost 700 women.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and up to
Now, after more than three years in prison for kidnapping, six men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation were killed during an incident at a market.
I hope that the judge who will decide in a week's time on the appeal in this case will realize the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation, but violence against women begins in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the general law on women's access to a life free of violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules cooperative are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and rape in marriage are criminal offences.
In addition, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a primary issue of youth education.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do tonight is to thank Mr Scott for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a real pleasure to work with him and the other spokesmen for the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position like this, which defends quality, which is committed to the development and value of rural areas, not only as

We are witnessing not only a traditional European culture but also real agents generating wealth and employment, which we so desperately need now in these moments of economic crisis and dramatic employment levels in some Member States.

We also like the defence that this European Parliament is maintaining and the position that the Committee on Agriculture has already made clear, namely that we are committed to quality to the fullest.
And to that extent, we are certainly committed to maintaining that distinction between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course, we reject the idea of lowering the quality and we want attention to be paid and Community production to be valued.
I welcome the words of Commissioner Cholo.
I was certainly pleased to hear him talk about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
Of course, we hope that you will hear that voice from this Parliament, which will be made clear in that vote tomorrow.

And finally, we hope that the European Commission will never again go ahead of this Parliament by banning things such as, for example, the standards for the marketing of fruit and vegetables, which have done so much damage to free competition in Europe.
We want the market disadvantages to be corrected and we also want to bet on quality, variety, food safety and the amount of production that is appropriate.
We also want Community productions and the quality of Community agri-food productions to be defended in the World Trade Organisation.
And for that we also have, of course, the work of Commissioner Cholos, because neither our producers nor our European consumers can remain defenseless.
Mr President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many treaties, to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should in heaven, yes, in the skin of the earth,
For example, by monitoring passenger rights and also by mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transport.
Nothing about minimum services, maximum services to all parties.
Madam President, when from different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Kolnitz or Kolmann, it is concluded that the European Union is not a European Union.
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of Members of the European Parliament are in trouble, which means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

It was a mandate that was already in the Treaties of Rome, and that is why the coordinators - and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr Howry and Mr Daff - have agreed on an amendment.
I hope that this House will support it precisely so that this issue, this question of the uniform electoral procedure, which is attached to the European Parliament, can be resolved soon.
It seems to me that with that we would eliminate this kind of questioning.
In his speech, Mr Trzaskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this House, and this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice-President Šefčovič, have highlighted.
And I agree - and we say this in the report in Article 1 - that the 18 should be included in the block, because if it were not, we would lose our representativeness.

And in order for them to join the bloc, in order to fulfil that act of political justice which is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, ladies and gentlemen, be pragmatic, because a transitory and exceptional situation also requires transitory and exceptional solutions.

And that is why I do not hide it. I do not like the possibility of Members of this House who have not come out of the 2009 elections entering this House. I say this very clearly in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and not
I ask this House, and therefore my report, to opt for this transitory, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, just.
Thank you all very much for your cooperation and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on 11 March, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay a well-deserved tribute to them from this Parliament today, recognizing the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a directive that protects the rights of the victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten and bear the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognized the dignity of the victims of terrorism and helped them in their right to protection and justice, which will soon be translated into a law.

It will honour all those who make it possible and that the first article, that support for the victims of terrorism, is that the right to justice is recognized and that no government ever pays a political price.

I appeal to all those who can defend the victims never to forget that true peace is that which is born of justice, and that is the only one that from Europe and from anywhere in the world we who believe in justice must defend.

Mr President, it has been necessary to face the abyss and the economic collapse so that the Heads of State and Government have understood that the way is not the way of more nationalism but the way of more Europe.
Measures have been taken in this direction, such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury.
Finally, although late, we have learned that we all sail on the same ship and that it is useless to deal with individual situations and, moreover, to do so in an improvised way.

But I wonder whether this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government, because what is left, ladies and gentlemen, is governance and what is missing is genuine government, if we are to be faithful to the will of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must push for all those reforms which are aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, by the way, nostalgic sovereignties.
Ladies and gentlemen, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only correct recipe for building a Europe which, otherwise, would vanish like a fugitive shadow.
Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of the INTA Committee, I would like to thank Mrs De Sarnez for the cooperation we have had.
Today more than ever, the Union for the Mediterranean, the strengthening of large projects and institutional development are needed.
Today more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the way out of the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

And to do this, it is necessary to boost and culminate trade and economic relations in the area, with short- and long-term measures, free trade area, removal of tariff barriers, opening of the north-south and south-south market.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will give the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new common approach, the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, within the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor called the Mediterranean corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain it is vital because this axis is a priority, given that it would communicate Algiers with Europe.
Not being excluded from other priority corridors, it would pass through Almeria, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.
And why, Commissioner Reding has said, has increased economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of two conditions.
It opened up the possibility of communicating with different ports in the Mediterranean area.
We must take economic momentum, we must be competitive, as the Commissioner also said, because more than 50 of Spain's exports are produced in this area.
So if we increase the issue of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Spanish rotating presidency on the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the crisis.
I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection.
That policy has not been crowned with success, largely because of the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency in January of last year.
This year, with the expulsion of the Member who speaks to you, when he was trying to visit the island with all the visas and all the legality to take care of the human rights of the island itself.
But that policy, that new policy undertaken by the Spanish Government, will bear fruit sooner rather than later.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is a regulation which is of the utmost importance to consumers and to the agri-food industry, because it is not at all easy to achieve a balanced labelling which contains everything essential but which is not so exhaustive as to complicate information.
This is a great report and the rapporteur should be congratulated on it.
I agree with her on the major issues relating to nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially if we take into account that the Commission did not comply with the
the commitment to establish such profiles and their conditions of use before 19 January 2009, as prescribed in Regulation No 1924-2006

There is one issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of the coexistence of national labelling standards, because it goes against the objective of legislation, which is harmonisation and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
As regards the indication of the country of origin, the current legislation provides that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it may mislead the consumer.
In addition, it is planned that there will always be a voluntary labelling.
Going further can involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies, without bringing any significant benefit, of course, to the consumer.
And as regards the use of different languages, I have to say that the Commission's proposal coincides with the existing Directive, which has worked well and has not raised any problems.
And reopening this debate can be dangerous and necessary and cause problems for the circulation of products.
Mr President, the best example of the goodwill we have is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the plenary.

But in addition to goodwill, I think we have to be practical when labeling food if we don't want to achieve the opposite effect of what we're pursuing, which is to confuse the consumer instead of helping him find out.
It is not a question of illustrating, but of warning, of informing you of what you can eat and to what extent.
It's a measure. You have to label fat, sugar, trans fats.
Yes, you do.
I am talking, in fact, about what affects cholesterol, about all those substances that affect what we have said, obesity and people's health.

Yes, but some other foods, with some other information, such as the place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or, for example, in a meat, i.e. the place of birth, the place of passage, the place of pasture, the place of sacrifice of the reindeer, can illustrate a lot, but they will end up confusing.

It is up to us to be practical and to ensure that this regulation remains as the one that will harmonise and as the one that will inform consumers or, if not, as the one that will confuse and impose more issues that, far from achieving better health care, will achieve greater degrees of confusion.

That is why I ask, for example, that some of us opt for the GDA, the amount of daily intake instead of the traffic lights, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will get fat, so consume only one.
The amount of daily intake in front of all kinds of codes is what some of us are proposing, so as not to confuse the consumer any more.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr Martin Fraguero, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency in a report such as this, Commissioner Asensio.
Mr Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement and to bring together all interests and to put on the table an own-initiative report, one of the first own-initiative reports.
The deployment of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary because of the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing capacity, but I would like to emphasize at this moment the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and jobs.
Health guarantees are important, sustainability is important and the protection of the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture must be enhanced and the scientific and research sector must also be strengthened.
Aquaculture is an opportunity - as Mr Martin Frareiro has said - within the CFP, as the Commissioner said.

We must give it a coherent framework of coordination, we must give it the possibility of regularization, because aquaculture can mean sufficiency, sustainability and economic resources, and I think this is important for Europe.
Mr President, in my view this excellent report sets out the guidelines which should inspire the new White Paper on transport, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report has several milestones that are worthy of review: the need for a financial fund as an indispensable instrument, the challenge of the growing demand for freight transport, the search for convenient solutions.
The imperative need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport, the diagnosis, in my view, that there should be no mere competition between the different modes of transport.
The rapporteur's statement, which I think is brave and fair, that rail or sea transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport, is a very important point.
In short, the concept of an efficient community is a concept of the future and must undoubtedly be supported in my view with all rigor.
It is your mistake, Mr President, a mistake of approach.
Did you think that you were really going to preside over Europe and influence the gears that make the complex European machinery work?
He even came to believe, because he let people close to you proclaim it, that the world was going to live under his presidency a stellar moment.
None of this has come true.
Let's go to some specifics.

In the six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between the political direction of the Presidency and, on the other hand, the work of the officials who have been working in the machine rooms.
It is the first to fail, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the Presidency of the Government, which has been woven rather by leaps and bounds.
However, I would like to highlight the efforts of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is that, Mr President, Spain has magnificent professional officials, and if there is anything to be regretted, it is that they are too marginalized in everyday reality.
That said, it is worth acknowledging that some worthwhile initiatives have been taken in the last six months.
Among them, I am pleased to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment that has been given to patients' rights in cross-border health care.
Moreover, the agreements on the new 2020 Strategy and, above all, those relating to the European External Action Service, both of which are still too fragile, have been left in the air.
It is regrettable what has happened with the European Protection Order for victims of gender-based violence, and the same bleak outcome has been offered by the European Protection Order.
It is a Community patent, which is essential for the lives of thousands of companies and is blocked in part by the linguistic problems which Spanish legislation encourages.

But it is all the great political actions that have been rewarded with a spectacular failure, from the Mediterranean summit to the European Union summit with the United States, the latter citing its own government as responsible for creating unreasonable expectations.
However, we must agree that not being able to carry out its policy towards Cuba has been highly positive for the Cubans.
Finally, the progress made towards a better European economic government cannot in any way be attributed to his presidency, which is loudly absent on the most relevant issues.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

A positive conclusion, yes, I want to draw from this experience. My fantasy of a convinced Europeanist is aroused by the thought that it may mean the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived so far.

This would be good news, because as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions by solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being plunged into the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr President, Mr Zapatero, believe me, I would have liked to have made a different speech today.
You have proposed a semester full of ambition and put such a high stakes on your claims that, compared to what has really been achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that your Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation which required leadership and credibility.
Your Honour has once reminded me that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was up to His Lordship to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Spanish Government that was imperatively demanding that its obligations be fulfilled.
In this context, positive achievements that have not been lacking have been neglected.
Your Lordship has had time to tell them, I have not.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And that's what it looks like. Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean summit and the announced European Union to the United States are failures of many calades.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not favoured the image of Spanish management, as Chapucero has described the way in which some respectable objectives have been achieved.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be so, despite the poor management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have kept up the pace, and thanks to that, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the value judgment that will be made of this Presidency will weigh more on the situation in Spain than it has done or has not done here.
It was hardly possible to lead such a difficult company that has placed its country in a stage of uncertainty and uncertainty.
In the best of cases, this Presidency has sadly proved to be irrelevant.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will be fully engaged in the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency will achieve what the Spanish Presidency has not achieved, namely to bring the discussions to a conclusion in such a way that the Member States commit themselves to maintaining a policy in the future.

A truly strong common agricultural policy, with a budget sufficient to meet the needs of the 27 Member States, the new and the old, and not to mention the fact that in 2005 there was a lack of money and modulation had to be invented.

In the next CAP reform we are playing on the viability of a sector which not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but which should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of poverty in the past, so it is necessary that the European Parliament should provide security and supply based on Community production as the main objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary and comes at a good time, because it has been shown that the abuses committed by the big distribution have severely disrupted the different links of the food chain.

The Bové report, which at some point may go too far in trying to be too interventionist, must be recognised from a perspective of the social market economy, as we advocate from the European People's Party, which must be recognised, which collects responses to the just demands of European producers.

It also provides transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always good, and gives many more opportunities and support to defend the weakest sectors of that chain and, of course, supports European consumers to learn more about that chain.

The European food industry could have been more taken into account in this report, perhaps it would have been very good, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also being taken to give fairness to these links in the chain, as requested in the Committee on the Environment, and to combat the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
It is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to ban them definitively.
It is also important that measures are taken to avoid difficult practices through white labels which are contrary to competition and to the Intellectual Property Act.

For all this, we must support the Bové report and we must support all the colleagues who, in the various parliamentary committees - INCO, ENVI and Agriculture - have shown that they work hard to ensure that this report finally comes to light and helps European producers to move forward.
The alarm bell rings and it's true.
And there is also the frustration, as is being heard in the speeches of this House, at the failure to achieve the Millennium Development Goals.
And the truth is, what we're playing at is a lot.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided that it will not continue to eat the small one, we would have to pay for it all from the generational pocket with our health and well-being as a bargaining chip.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering conservation measures.

But as the unfulfilled objectives show, it seems that there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination - which has also been mentioned here - but also for expansion to go beyond our very limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked up in a ghetto area, as it sometimes seems to be done, by taking a look at it from time to time.
Biodiversity lives and has no borders, it crosses the whole earth with a domino effect in which if one chip falls, all the others fall.

I draw attention to the need for a global and more Community will, especially with regard to the soil, because subsidiarity, as the only method for managing the soil or forests, can be one of the new fearsome enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote to be taken and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on land would help to preserve the whole territory.

A European Union so varied, so diverse for good and for evil, and so lacking in political will on the part of the States, and so in need of more and more European Union, with all the extension of the word in what it means more Union also for the soil.

Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs McAvan, not only in the substance but also in the form, because she has done so in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
I would also like to thank the experts of the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The aim of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the surveillance, transparency and communication of the safety of medicines once they have been marketed, especially with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may produce.

It should be noted that the European Committee on Pharmacovigilance has been set up to evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on the safety problems that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

It is very important that the solution reached for the notification to the Supervisory Board of suspicions of adverse reactions is adopted by both the Member States and those responsible for the marketing of medicinal products.

Ultra-vigilance will be the only source of information, but at the same time the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected will be informed, and this is very important.
It should also be noted that consumers have the possibility of communicating any adverse reaction and, in this respect, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal
The European Medicines Agency, which in turn links with the portals of each Member State, will help to improve citizens' knowledge of the safety of the medicines they consume.
And finally, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in the protection of public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This Directive and Regulation will contribute significantly to this by improving not only the current procedures but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.

I very much appreciate the rapporteur's effort to accept some suggestions and, of course, her defence of the copyright, which I share, but the inclusion of the infringement and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the

The recognition of sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the exclusion of mass exchanges as a possible offence in the alternative resolution, make it impossible to vote in favour of either of the two reports in Liza.
The Galois report has aroused great interest and could have been timely, but the background of the debate is too much focused on the debate in favour or against the French law called
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

I hope that we will reach a common position in the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposal for a directive which will soon be before Parliament, as Commissioner Barnier has announced.
On that occasion we will try to achieve a more balanced position than today, taking into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and Members of this Parliament.
A huge financial crisis has had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been lost, in part, to strengthen the common institutions of Europe, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a competence area
It is a pity, moreover, that progress has not been made in a similar integration to that which occurred with the central banking system.
We've made progress, but we need to keep climbing the mountain.

Madam President, as a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA killed my brother and his wife in Seville, I am addressing this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its President for allowing terrorists to

The Bolivarian guerrillas are trained in Venezuelan territory, on the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubilla, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the fact that an international search and capture order weighs on him, which is a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Spanish Government take decisive action in the face of this grave humiliation of all Spaniards.
Zapatero cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our civil guards torturers, who have been and will be an example of courage in the fight against ETA.
Nor can it look the other way in the face of this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
Zapatero cannot shake the hand of a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The President of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give an answer that he deserves and that any citizen on foot would give if he had the opportunity to do so.
On 14 February 2008, as a gift of St. Valentine's Day, the Conference of Presidents decided that the intergroups should meet only on Thursdays.
Since then, we have tried to resolve this issue.
We haven't got it.
The intergroups today, Mr President, have to meet on a date which is not the right one.
They almost never have rooms and they never have interpretation.

I am speaking today not only as President of the Intergroup on Poverty and Human Rights, but with the mandate of most of the intergroups in this House, and therefore of the members of this House who are part of these intergroups.
And I solemnly ask the Conference of Presidents to reconsider and annul the decision of 14 February 2008 and return to the previous situation of freedom of the intergroups.
And if he does not, I say kindly also that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this House and it will decide who in this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr President, on the International Day against Trafficking in Persons for the Purpose of Social Exploitation, some data have been made public which should make us act as replicas.
More than 90 per cent of the prostitution in Europe is the result of blackmail and extortion.

And in the face of this data, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing all that is necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter, which we adopted with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest trade in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not been able to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries such as Spain are making important efforts in this direction by persecuting traffickers, raising awareness among citizens and promoting plans to reintegrate victims.
But it's not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next trade directive is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to make it difficult to access, for example, the offer to advertise in all kinds of media, as well as to increase bilateral cooperation with third countries to combat this scourge from the outset.
We have an opportunity.
I draw the attention of this Parliament to continue to be the vanguard of citizens' rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the External Service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to do so, we must act with great ambition, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are being transferred or retained in the short term and for wars between the various European institutions.
What is happening now, on the contrary, is to have a general vision of what the European Union should be in the world, that is to say, to do just the opposite.
This is what happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices have been heard from Europe, and not all of them brave.
One of the exceptions is that the President of this Parliament, Mr Buzek, is the author of a brilliant and dignified statement.

Mr President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of the knife and knife industry, which in my region, the land of Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of more than 8 jobs, an element of identity and a bet on the future of handicrafts as a source of employment.

And it is that the sealed Meiden, the knives, has long been claimed by social groups such as Preku and fought for by the Government of Castile and Mancha, with the unanimous support of its regional parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism, it is a commitment to transparency and commercial rules of the game and the fight against the competition of the loyal.

It is to increase the decision-making capacity of consumers when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of the product but also the quality mark of the place of origin or the social conditions in which it is produced.

And, above all, it will mean a new horizon of optimism for many people who are having a hard time, but who today look at us with the thought that we have not been indifferent when it comes to betting on fairer trade, yes, but also to give added value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions of European workers.
That is why I thank the rapporteur and Mr Menéndez del Valle for their political support and their social awareness on this important issue for my country.
Mr President, let's see if I can calm down a bit in this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some of the countries and some of the Member States that make up the European Union are still present in this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there were at least a global common position in this world forum.
And what would, in my opinion, be that common position?
In my modest opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a global agreement to deal with the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement.
Thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe must represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public
In short, it must be known that in the global world, in this global game, only those who play the national cards lose.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we are in a position to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Meissner.
I think there were different positions found and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important issue.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Transport has decided that all the seas are protected in a similar way and, for that reason, it argues that otherwise there would be a situation of unfair competition.

We accept the position of the majority in favour of a legal situation with uniform rules for the whole of the Union, but I will not spare your lords the opportunity to point out clearly that it also implies a certain lack of equity.
It is clear that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that checks on sulphur limit values will have to be more rigorous in their case.
Port-related measures, such as solutions to reduce transport times and handling costs, should be evaluated positively.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have a pending subject.
If they do not undertake a decisive liberalisation of the ports, they will not be able to extend the central role they must play in the context of commodity.
The promotion of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific repercussions of climate change is also welcome, ladies and gentlemen.
I think this is a positive report, which must be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs in the context of a serious disaster, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

In this respect, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the revision of the Regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency reinforces the role that the Agency should play in preventive inspections and subsequent tasks of cleaning up hydrocarbon spills.
My personal judgment, Madam Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks must be strengthened by the mandate required for that purpose.
Mr President, integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries and aquaculture policy and not subordinate it to other policies.
We must all respond to the environmental and economic problems of society in general and of the fishing sector.

to create more and better jobs, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy and to promote the governance of our seas that have no barriers and have no sustainability problems, as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working for an integrated maritime policy, this would be working for the environment and sustainability.
Mr President, recently the Church of Our Lady of Help was raided in Baghdad and 58 people were killed, most of them women and children, on the mere condition of being Christians.
Al Qaeda has taken over the authorship with pride of the feat.
It is not an isolated event, but the culmination of persecution and attacks on Christians in Muslim-majority countries.
expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo, how long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Buzek has made an institutional statement.
The statement of condemnation by the High Representative, Mrs Ashton, has been limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
Why is the mobile not mentioned? The condition of Christians, which is the unambiguous cause of the massacre.
I haven't heard anything from Mr. Zapatero, I haven't heard anything from President Erdogan.
Mr. Erdogan, what is the Alliance of Civilizations for?
I feel sorry for our fanaticism and our cowardice.

Inevitably comes to my mind the weeping and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in the complex Europe.
I also thank the Commissioner, and I share the wish of this House.
I want the proposals of the Europeans to get the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, the importance of cities in the preservation of the environment must be emphasised.

There is a pact between more than a thousand mayors of the European Union which demonstrates the existence of a recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose action is decisive if we are to succeed.
The big words we use are worthless if we don't have the collaboration of the mayors of the cities.
To do this, it is very important that emissions are disclosed, as cities produce almost 80 of greenhouse gases.
Today there is no such disclosure, nor, what is worse, a common pattern for the very measurement of these emissions.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 dissemination project, which already hosts information from thousands of companies and which I think could also be used by the municipalities.
Without their participation, without the participation of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action is left in the dust, the dust from which we want to escape.

Mr President, some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too mild, given the magnitude of the repression of human rights in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country with no sovereignty or legal title.
But what is important is the message that the whole of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate their violence.
Yesterday I was speaking about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which has sadly failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia and Darfur, I hope, however, to avoid that of Western Sahara, and we do not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague, as I said, but this time for war crimes.
Mr President, Commissioner, the directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework governing toy safety.
It's a big step in the right direction, because it points us in the right direction, but it's not enough.
We must always be vigilant and careful that the toys that are marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether by substances considered toxic, such as EMR, fragrances and other dangerous substances, such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary that the rules to be followed be clearer on the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers arising from inadequate use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of the child's behaviour.
We must be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances based on solid studies and be more rigorous in market surveillance and toy imports.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between Member States and to have the joint work of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are ready to make their Christmas purchases and we must give them the assurance that the products they buy meet all the safety requirements.
In this debate we have clearly seen that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The various political groups have expressed their support for this directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
So I wonder what is the obstacle to the adoption of this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there that something as necessary and simple as protecting victims equally across Europe will finally become a reality?
In the hope that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I am addressing the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have...
We have overcome the legal loopholes in our negotiations and I applaud the Commission's recognition of our work, as we recognise what it will do in the future.

We must not, therefore, exclude ourselves, but help ourselves by adopting today this more concrete instrument and tomorrow the broader package of measures to help the victims which the Commission will present and with which I am committed to collaborating.
So let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether men, women or children.
Let us help those who look to us today to give them a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their security and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the Group of the European People's Party will be voting enthusiastically on this report, and I would first of all like to thank the rapporteurs, the Commission and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s the term democratic deficit.
With it we meant that in the European Union decisions were taken only by the Council of Ministers on the proposals of the Commission and that this Parliament was only consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Treaty of Maastricht, the Treaty of Amsterdam, the Treaty of Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, the Treaty of Lisbon, has been
And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of the national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we round it off today with this citizens' legislative initiative, which was due, in the work of the Convention, to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.
And I would like to recall here the names of Jürgen Meyer, our German Social Democrat colleague, and Annan Lamassoure, who took that initiative to the Convention and made it pass.
So I think we've completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have put on the table the death certificate of the democratic concept of EDEX.
It is now up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union budget, we will fulfil what is expected of us, a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I think it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
Mr President, in January 2012 400 Spanish egg producers could disappear, about 30% of the total in my country, with the loss of 300 tonnes of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those two million tonnes, and we would only get them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with a lot of intelligence.
This 1999 directive, which requires us to increase the space for laying hens, requires us to act with intelligence and a possible vision, because otherwise

We will only succeed in weakening European production and giving extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space for birds is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a directive which requires a great deal of effort on the part of European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost is about EUR 600 million, but we must not forget that it also has an economic impact which extends to the egg industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask your support for the amendment by the Group of the European People's Party to paragraph 2, which calls for a solution to be sought, at least for the responsible farms of responsible industrialists who are proceeding to the transformation of their farms and who in January 2012 will be almost finished.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to farms and preventing a situation of shortages in the Community market from night to morning, consequently raising prices for the consumer.

It is a question of respecting the directive, of giving an opportunity to the egg and egg product industry, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr President, I think it is right to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs Grossetête and Mrs Dagmar Romberen from my own group, for the work they have done to remove a norm from stagnation and make it useful, because this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

And to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that must guarantee citizens the safety and quality that they choose at all times, especially because it also allows us to clearly regulate the role of the States, both those of origin who have to pay and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but that this must be the beginning of a much greater advance which, as Mrs Römberg said, makes this directive a mere procedure, because the level of equality achieved in all the States makes it unnecessary for every citizen to travel to every country.

And in that fight we must obtain a norm which guarantees more the right of citizens to the attention they have to receive, to benefits, to citizenship and to security, than the mere right they already have to mobility between States.
Equality is what the Union will do, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour, as did the rest of our group, but I would not leave here without expressing my concern that they have been included in this directive.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

I hope that this inclusion will have the same effectiveness as the good legislation we adopted in this very House, both with the Transplant Directive and with the Action Plan, very recently and with a practical totality of support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant not to undermine with this inclusion the good work done by such successful organizations as the National Transplant Organization of Spain and, of course, with the claim to save twenty thousand lives that we had both in the Transplantation Directive and in the Action Plan that we repeat here.
I therefore make it clear and say that we will continue to be attentive to the compliance of this directive in this respect.
Mr President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data are worrying. The World Health Organization estimates that more than 300 million people are infected each year involuntarily with a sexually transmitted disease.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is worrying because of an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Even, as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe in access to sexual health services, depending on the States and, within them, on the level of income of citizens.
To combat all this, a European strategy is needed.

Only five Member States have plans in this regard, but in all of them it has been possible to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases and also the number of abortions.

We need a common strategy that focuses on prevention from an educational point of view, that expands information policies, that increases efforts in family planning and that facilitates access to contraceptive methods.
A transversal and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of all citizens to sexual health in the best conditions of safety and health.
Mr President, in the face of strong social tensions, the great agreement on social consultation in Spain between the Government, the trade unions and the employers can only be warmly welcomed.
This agreement is an example for Europe, where such milestones have not occurred for a long time.

I would also like to take very much into account the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels on Tuesday 8 February.
Mr Candido then insisted on the need to extend the concertation to a European scale and on the need to have a voice and trade union initiatives in this Europe of ours.
That's how it should be.
Mr President, by keeping our distance on terrorism and immigration, I have found that the European Union is unfortunately moving in the face of emergencies, such as a serious economic crisis.

An attack or a mass landing of immigrants, such as the one currently taking place in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia to the Italian coast can lead to a chronicle of an announced death.

The journey of hope can end in a damned journey and will weigh on our consciences, on the consciences of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we'll put our hands on our heads, but the next day we'll forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common migration policy will continue to be a dream as long as European countries do not commit themselves with sufficient economic means for Frontex to be effective.
It doesn't cost anything to talk, but you have to act.
Do you really believe that Frontex can now guarantee the security of Europe's borders?
I don't think he did.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other countries of the Maghreb do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe and do so in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must help them.
So solidarity, responsibility, but above all truth, when it comes to talking about a European common migration policy, which is more necessary today than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is still normal that in the OECD countries the highest equity indices in citizens' income are given in the field of pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost only 20% of their value in 2008 and are still, to this day, far from the required levels of solvency.

All this shows that, at a time of inevitable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be done in a transversal way, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies of birth or employment conciliation.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
Finally, I regret that the text does not put limits on the abuse of the figure of grants in enterprises, since, as a general rule, they are excluded from all types of social contribution.
In my view, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers, who, if they are being demanded more to have a decent pension, would also need to be punished less to access decent work.
