Mr President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on the economic and social aspects but also on the territorial.
Territorial cohesion pursues harmonious development between territories in order to enable their citizens to make the most of their territorial singularities.
But in order to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union facing the same challenges and the same problems.

This is the objective of the European Union Strategy for the Atlantic Region, a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the States of the region, including maritime research, maritime surveillance and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period after 2013, in particular with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, it is first and foremost necessary that this strategy be based on renewed multi-level governance, based on closer participation of public authorities.
Member States, the European Union and stakeholders in the private sector and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who a hundred years ago fought for labour and economic rights and for women's vote.
We have come a long way in these 100 years, but much remains to be done, and true equality is still a dream and discrimination against women is a real fact.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to life is threatened, whose dignity is violated and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this Women's Day, to show my support and my hope to all the women who, in the North African Revolution, are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half a man, neither in the Arab countries nor anywhere else in the world.
So we are worth the same and we deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who charge half as much as men, that domestic violence affects especially women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and of course I promise that I will continue to work.
Mr President, I would like to express my agreement with the opinion of the Members who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on the European Council's willingness to accept the role of the institutions mentioned.
Because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of economic governance, led by a European Union.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so what is the Commission's position?

In other words, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are engaged ends up on the intergovernmental path, which is a dead end or the path of the predominance of a few States, because all this would frustrate the reform.
Ladies and gentlemen, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of the things that reinforces and balances this delicate building.
There are still essential points to be improved, so we have to send the report back to the Commission.
This is not the end of the parliamentary interpellation of this report.
The initial proposal was bad.
That is what the consumer associations at national and European level told us.
And I am particularly grateful for the work of the Union of Consumers of Asturias and its President, the tireless Dace Alonso.
We have succeeded in rejecting the general principle of maximum harmonization of the old Article 4.

It must be said loud and clear that maximum harmonization by establishing the same protection in all Member States would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, since there is a greater tradition in various countries in the protection of consumer rights.

In any case, I would like to point out that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

The burden of proof is placed on the individual clauses, so it is up to the traders to demonstrate that the clauses have been negotiated individually, that they are outside the generally established framework, that the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable way.
We are still opposed to the establishment of maximum harmonization in relation to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of traders believe that full harmonisation in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr President, Commissioner, allow me first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Schwab and Mrs Gerhardt on the excellent work they have done.
and a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but about not cutting back on rights already existing in some of the Member States.
Because if we want and we seek to establish a genuine internal market for relations between companies and consumers, we must
In parallel, a balance must be struck between a high level of protection of consumer rights and the defence of the competitiveness of enterprises.
This balance is achieved by agreeing on a minimum harmonisation and by allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations to improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a Community standard to mean the deprivation of protection of many consumers and users.
I welcome the fact that the negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights which have been established so far are not curtailed.

Mr President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis and that, moreover, we are either not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the speed necessary to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum on Nature is calling for all of us to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow.
But it's not enough.
Europe cannot continue to rely on energies that are not its own, that are far away or on insecure energies.
We need to help the States build a new energy model in which renewable energy is at the heart of the new
And we must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because renewables and efficiency are undoubtedly the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to call on all the countries of the Union to join this call, this will of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 reductions by up to 30%, because this would show that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also at the forefront of its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament I have done so to denounce violence against women and I am here again to fight it.

I must say that not only do I not get tired of it, but I consider it essential to continue to speak publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a resonance box, and this Parliament is the best.

I have a loudspeaker at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, the legislators, to force the States to punish the aggressors, according to the gravity of the crime, and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives and that children have suffered equally, I believe that it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, such as that recognised by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe that it is necessary to continue to insist again and again on leaving the victims, as we have already done in the European order for the protection of victims, of which I was rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has had great consensus and support from the outset, which shows that when it comes to addressing domestic violence, which affects all members of the family,
Families, children, the elderly, women and men must not be a reason for political opportunism, since it is an honour for all of us to advance in the solution of this social crisis.
The first is not to be silent and the second is to get to work, because although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We are doing something wrong, and so it is time to forget the demagoguery and to think and to move from words to deeds, providing more help and the necessary reaction so that women can live with dignity and security.
And security, so that all the victims know that I will always be here to continue to lend my voice to them until, among all of us, we succeed in defeating this...
A terrible enemy, who sadly ends the lives of so many innocent people.
Mr President, Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and the European social construction.

Because with the adoption of these reports we are not only moving towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for more progress towards Europe and strengthening social rights.
Europe must respond to the new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that creates sensitive growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the insertion of a social clause in all legislation relating to the internal market, which puts citizens at the centre of our attention and priority and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr President, the blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health.

A disease that we were fighting through the activated vaccine, the use of which leads to the creation of restricted areas for the circulation of animals, because the use of these vaccines can cause an unwanted circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to those areas where previously infected animals had been found, creating a double harm to livestock farmers, on the one hand, disease and, on the other hand, restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disturbances that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows the development of new and broader strategies, which is truly important, of prevention in the fight against this disease.
It is therefore of the utmost importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use and that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, compliance with the provisions of our Treaties, especially with regard to the correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to enter into force before the summer, because with our delay, with its delay, we would only be harming the farmers.

Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has done following the complaint lodged by FEPEX, the Spanish organisation of fruit and vegetable producers and exporters, on the basis of the report published in 2007 by the Union's anti-fraud agency OLAF.

I think that the conclusions of that report are very clear and fully justify the fact that the European Commission had already taken action a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at least as regards the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to resolve possible pitfalls to which the entry price regulation may give rise, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without having previously resolved the failings of the import regime in force.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time that the European Commission took its responsibilities seriously and began to investigate where fraud occurs and eventually called for the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I do not think that a new agreement with Morocco should in any way be ratified without the details we have set out having been resolved.

Our objective is not to curb the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that such agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As regards the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only asks for guarantees that the agreed measures are effectively complied with, and this is only possible through the reform of the price regime when it enters into force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the Commission has already concluded.

Moreover, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to control it, an important economic effort should be demanded of the Member States, but it is also true that we have been calling for a long time for a European customs border system, on the same example as that of the United States, to ensure that effective control.

Mr President, Commissioner, dealing with this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves these measures which require the approval of the World Trade Organization and the Commission's preliminary proposal to Parliament is different from that sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan, we understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, as long as they take into account the sensitivities of the
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Union has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

But this report has enabled us to verify that, probably, the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade cannot be dealt with with the urgency that these acts need, so we should learn for the future.

It will help Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, since it does not take into account the effects of European industry on the timelines for the application of sensitive products.
It would even delay the implementation of these measures because they did not coincide with the outstanding text to be adopted by the WTO.
We therefore consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think we will have to vote against it.
Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.

It is an agreement which we should all congratulate ourselves on because it affects the daily lives of all citizens, but with the constructive spirit which characterizes me I would like to make a few points.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant but above all understandable and uniform information.
For consumers on the components of textile products, exhaustive information will be useless if the citizens are not able to decipher it.
We have taken a necessary but not sufficient positive step. We should go further and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European system of labelling carvings on the basis of body dimensions, because the first thing we encounter when we buy a garment is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and seek the harmonization of sizes.
Mr President, three notes on the situation created around cucumbers.
I am the grandson of a German and I have great affection for that country, but it is clear that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and recklessness.

On the other hand, if we look at European action, we see that the action taken by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been sloppy, very vague and imprecise, it has not been able to coordinate or direct.
Thirdly, the injured parties are entitled to prompt financial compensation.
But for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organise in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a great exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on cucumber.
We must claim the lost honor, a pleasant expression of the German writer Heinrich Böll, we must claim the lost honor of the cucumber producers.
Europe is the right scenario for this.
Mr President, first of all, I am obliged to express my sincere regret at the 23 victims who have already died, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis, it must be said, is the most conclusive proof that the European Union must greatly improve its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The Member States involved have shown slowness, inefficiency and inefficiency, and at this stage, after 23 deaths, we still do not know where the problem comes from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems it causes by its irresponsible actions or inaction in times of crisis such as the present, causing cases of economic ruin, of destruction of jobs that were previously
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.

German women, very uninformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms, while the population remained exposed without knowing it to the bacterium, believing they were avoiding it, the citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should propose to the Ministers, at the Agriculture Council in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., that part of the EUR 2 million that exist be used as unused surpluses from the common agricultural policy.
We need those EUR 2 billion to repair, where possible, the damage caused.

To do this, it is necessary to look for a legal perch that allows this to be done, a legal perch that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cows or dioxins, and that should be found now.
So, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you have to live up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt and from the outset, and also, with their own funds, carry out communication campaigns to establish the confidence of consumers in the loss of horticultural production.

Mr President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union is going to bring the dead back to life, and I hope that what is being done will prevent more from happening and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to be there.

We do not know the causes, surely, but we do know some things that we have to call by name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German Federal Government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a state on another continent.

The pride that Mrs Merkel and her Minister of Health have in addressing other States with unusual frequency, if they had translated it into diligence and effectiveness to coordinate, some of the things that have happened would not have happened.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a state that has been the Spanish State and for its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to the family ruin of thousands of people and small businessmen and has long discredited the economy.
I ask you to go to the Council today and ask for full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for life for the dead.
and that the control systems are reviewed.
And that Mrs Merkel be held accountable.
And to be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
And to hold him responsible for some of the damage he's done.
You can't ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
You can't ignore your responsibilities.
You cannot take refuge under a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little more good management and a little less conservatism would have gone very well if this crisis had not escaped our hands and Spain and other farmers in the south had not suffered its painful consequences.
You review the controls, you review the alert systems and you ask for responsibilities, because in Spain we are asking you, Commissioner, the Council and the German State.
Mr President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and the culprits have been sought, not the cause.

The system has not worked we have 22 dead, 1 affected and we do not know the cause three weeks later and, appealing to a principle of precaution without scientific basis - I repeat without scientific basis - Spain is blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were contaminated, they weren't contaminated, I repeat, because some opposing versions have been heard around here.
But for you to see the importance of what these words have caused, 300 jobs could be affected, a loss of trust.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I give you the reason, Commissioner, you know no borders, we ask for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at the moment, it has the highest number of affected, but Spain is not to blame.
We are asking for compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as we European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and responsibility.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused the Spanish cucumbers and, in particular, the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería, which were models of exploitation and which will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of unemployed families are wondering why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia but in all of agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that the experts will find a quick solution, I call on the Commission, when it speaks to the Council today, to call for immediate economic and moral measures for all the producers who, from Andalusia and from all over Europe, look to us with indignation but with hope.
Mr President, instead of promoting research and European collaboration, the German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And no one in Germany has yet resigned or offered repairs to the extent of the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious problem of credibility.
Mrs Merkel's treatment of the countries of the South in terms of agriculture and also in terms of finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that, it lacks credit.
Mr President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and some other countries have coincided in their reluctance to accept the so-called Eurovision.

The coincidence, the criticism, is due to our condition as peripheral countries, which, in the end, will be the ones to pay for this singular debt that will be collected by the states of the European Union that have geographical centrality.
The ratio that inspires the Eurovignette incurs great contradictions and the support speech is getting weaker every day.

Although the rationality of the internalisation of external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end it is not supported that, in order to alleviate congestion, only heavy-duty vehicles are penalized, leaving tourists out, in the same terms as the old motto of "who pays pollutes" is applied with obvious discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was envisaged as a source of financing for infrastructure, will ultimately only be allocated to the financing of trans-European networks and not necessarily to the financing of the European networks.

It is a simple recommendation that the Minister of Finance in turn will distribute the proceeds in order to make them more convenient for the interests of his country, within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing more than a further blow to road freight transport, which, today, is the only way the internal market is allowing.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more crude in the context of an economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products on world markets cannot be allowed to be experimented with, which could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new added costs.

In fact, the food crisis, which has recurred recklessly on Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and huge losses for those who are penalized by the Eurovignette, the freight forwarders and the farmers of primary crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all understand, ladies and gentlemen, that when I take the presidency of the session, I express my grief and consternation at the death of Jorge Semprun, who died a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Sanprún we celebrate those who were prisoners in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable committed writer, a particular collaborator of our programme The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I also mourn his death as a companion and friend of his and I will ask President Buzek to send to his family and to the Government of Spain a message of pity and solidarity which I am sure we all share here.
the creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the construction of Europe.
We can't keep our eyes closed.
It is incoherent to have a single currency and at the same time to lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In particular, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a non-restricted competition between the debt issuances of the States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonisation of tax policies that guarantee equality for citizens, combat tax fraud and help to define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, I'll be told, elementary.
But you have to repeat them over and over again, because no one listens to them.
And it is precisely because they do not listen that those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are running.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument to reduce the differences in development between regions and States.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe, which citizens have lately only associated with harsh adjustment and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of solidarity, the European project and social justice, will have to take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 strategy; second, to take into account the needs and characteristics of the

Thirdly, to maintain the principle of graduality in the perception of funds so that the regions do not abandon the objective of convergence, avoiding abrupt changes in the perception of aid, and fourthly, to promote a system
equitable
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing strict budgetary adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes a good note.

In defence of fundamental rights, I ask the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastian as the European Capital of Culture, because I believe that it has been chosen following a political criterion, which is discrimination against other aspiring cities.

The President of the Court said that she was chosen to support the peace process and that I know that in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA which, to this day, has not given up its weapons and which, two months ago, succeeded in having its political arm, Bild, rule among other municipalities, that of San Sebastián.
I do not think that we in Europe should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and who will make propaganda to divide the blame between victims and murderers.
Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course, not in San Sebastian, where our comrades, such as Major Oreja, Iturgaiz, Salva or myself, must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not the culture of shooting.
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No, and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastian is a free city for all, let them re-apply and, in the meantime, let them learn the culture of respecting those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batazuna and his heirs in the institutions, they don't deserve it.
Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful cooperation they have shown in drafting it.
I say the same about the other Members of the Commission, colleagues in this Parliament.
Sixty years ago the European Coal and Steel Community was created, and there is nothing better to commemorate this event than to debate energy infrastructure in Europe now.

Today, the European Union has clearly set the objectives of its policy: the European common internal market, the promotion of renewable energy as a means or instrument of combating climate change, security of supply and diversification of its sources.
The Treaty of Lisbon has enshrined a title on energy, the 21st, which sets out these commitments I have just mentioned and, in addition, the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well, the aim of the report we have drawn up is to correct energy infrastructures which, in the opinion of the European Commission, are disrupted and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we are faced with a spectacular increase in wind power generation in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south.
Europe and North Africa, with the problems arising from large-scale electricity storage, with the need to recharge electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All this is impossible to tackle today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.
It is therefore a question of making progress in the coming years in determining the necessary infrastructure, establishing the criteria for selecting projects of European interest.
b) by abolishing energy islands; c) by ensuring the implementation of these projects within reasonable deadlines and by arbitrating formulas to resolve the conflicting issue of
Authorisation and licensing procedures in the Member States, ensuring funding that attracts and drives private investment, without prejudice to the public support needed.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are key ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report because we have
We have believed that by reducing energy demand, we can reduce dependence on imports, with the consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A fundamental concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licences and authorisations intended to allow the execution of the necessary works.
Those who are now eternal.
And they are terrified by the opposition of the populations to seeing towers or other types of facilities grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, early information to citizens has been considered and a warning system has been established in the event that the authorities of a State do not respond to a request within a reasonable time.
We are facing ambitious targets for which the participation of all is necessary.
In this respect, it is essential for companies in the sector to demand a stable regulatory framework, the best way of ensuring the financing of their efforts.
Until now, the European Union's energy policy, both outside and inside its borders, has lacked a decidedly European impetus.
Europe must speak with one voice, a voice that is well audible and resonates fully in the vault of the European building, because it is our energy fragility that we are talking about.
to do everything possible to build an energy-solid and vigorous Europe, worthy of succeeding, this year on the anniversary of that great invention which was the CEC, our cradle precisely.
Mr President, whenever there is a commitment that allows progress, it must be welcomed, but I do not think that the commitment we have reached is to die of a stroke of happiness either.
We have to be cautious in the happiness snatchers we have.

In a continent like this, with problems of overeating, heart problems, overweight, we need to speed up and we need to ban the addition of fat to food as soon as possible, as Denmark has done, as Spain has done, as Australia has done.

What the European economy and companies need is trust.
Accounting audits are nowadays burdened by the concentration and lack of independence of auditors and do not contribute to generating the desired confidence that will revive our economy.
It would not be out of the question to abolish the legal obligation of the auditors.
Why not?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and of the markets, we must carry out a profound reform of the audits so that they are a real added value and not a mere legal burden.
Large auditors use audit services as a presentation card for their future clients.
Once familiar with the company, they offer more expensive complementary services, often to offset the low prices of strict auditing.
We have a problem of price distortion in the sector.

These complementary services already account for almost 50% of turnover, so the major auditors do not want to lose audit services, but not for the audit itself, but to maintain and increase complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four big ones, which dominate European markets above the 90s.
As such, oligopolies control prices and set barriers to entry for new competitors, using intangibles such as the international image of the mark.

It is true that this brand image can be based on certain advantages, but it does not always mean greater efficiency, given the legislative diversity in the accounting States susceptible to particular treatment in each Member State.
I share the objectives of the Green Paper, the independence and concentration of the sector and the means to use rotation, joint audits
Calls for tenders, reinforcement of professional scepticism, prevalence of the substance over the form, separation of audit services from non-audit services.
I have tried to transfer them to my report to the extent that the parliamentary majorities have allowed me to do so and the modest scope of it.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is only a small step towards achieving new legislation that cures, in this field of auditing, the mistakes that have led us to this terrible economic crisis.
I encourage you, Mr Barnier, to continue your examination and to achieve a good result.

It is undoubtedly necessary to meet all the requirements for accepting the use of these scanners, namely the preservation of fundamental rights and, within these, in particular the dignity and privacy of the passenger, non-discrimination, the protection of personal data and the protection of health.
Thus it was established what kind of scanners were suitable to ensure, on the one hand, the safety of the passenger and, on the other, to preserve his rights.
Scanners will not use ionising radiation, will not be mandatory for States or citizens, and will all protect the rights described above.

The Commission has taken up all these concerns, it is true, in its future legislation, but it includes, in addition to standard figure scanners, the possibility of another modality which, by guaranteeing the same set of rights, allows the inspection of an image, even if it is blurred, of the passenger.
We accept the reasons why it has been obliged to include this alternative as an authorised control method.
Parliament also advocates the need to ensure fair competition and thus escape any monopoly temptation.
However, today we ask the Commission to maintain all the principles we have defended in my report, all the guarantees for the preservation of fundamental rights.
It is also encouraged to work with industry and Member States to ensure that in the near future only automatic protection standards are used and that no inspector is needed to visualize any image.

Our British colleagues in the House of Commons, in honour of the admirable historical parliamentary and democratic tradition of their country, have highlighted the intolerable practices of the Murdoch Group.

I welcome the directive on the rights of victims of crime, including terrorism, and as a Spaniard who has directly suffered the cruelty of the terrorist organization ETA, I would like to thank President Buzek for his support for my country and its victims.

Madam President, I understand the satisfaction of many at this new ETA communiqué, but I must remind you that we cannot yet throw bells in the air, because to date they have neither surrendered their weapons, nor dissolved, nor apologized to their victims.
It is also important that your lords know that in Spain we do not have to achieve any peace between two sides, because there has been no war.

My brother, Alberto Jiménez Becerrilla, murdered by ETA in Seville, along with his wife, did not come from the war, he went to his home where his three children were waiting for him, who would never see him again.
We have an obligation to explain to my brother's children that their parents were better than those who killed them.
If we accept a end without winners or losers, we will be teaching those children that by killing, political goals are achieved.

I therefore ask for the support of this House so that it does not allow itself to be deceived by the terrorists of ETA and their accomplices and listens to the sincere voices of the victims, who want only the peace that is born of justice.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this crisis is teaching us a great deal, but there is one which seems to me to be of particular importance and it is precisely the following.
It will be necessary in the future to amend the Treaties in order to thoroughly reform the decision-making and agreement-making procedure within the European institutions.
The diabolical system in place today is slow, desperate and, moreover, full of whims.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, citizens are calling on Europe to find solutions to the problems and for Europe to be able to achieve a sustainable economic recovery and to contribute to the simplification and flexibility of regulations.
The mobility of professionals is not only a fundamental right enshrined in the Treaties, it is also a key factor for the modernisation of the labour market and economic development.
It is therefore necessary to adapt and update the scheme for the recognition of professional qualifications to the realities of work and to the demands and needs of professionals and consumers.

The Commission's future proposal should envisage greater transparency and simplification in the rules for the recognition of professional qualifications, an evaluation of the compensatory measures to solve existing problems, and a greater

clarification of the criteria on language knowledge to ensure the quality of the services provided and to protect the safety of consumers and patients, and greater cooperation and coordination between the competent authorities and national contact points.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must put professionals and consumers at the heart of the single market.
Only in this way can we build a way out of the financial and economic crisis based on sustainable knowledge and social progress.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with an extremely sensitive issue.
On the one hand, we must take into account cultural traditions and the important sustainable contribution of gambling to society in some States, such as my own, through education, culture and sport.
And on the other hand, we must fight crime linked to gambling and protect consumers, especially the most vulnerable, to avoid excessive or pathological gambling.
I therefore believe that the principle of active subsidiarity based on cooperation between national administrations should prevail in this area.

However, we must be ambitious and commit ourselves to the development of common rules and coordinated joint action against irregular online gambling operators operating without the necessary national licences.
We must also ensure transparency and make possible non-discriminatory competition that pursues the public interest and consumer protection.
Finally, we must promote the formation of a network of national organisations dealing with gambling addicts in order to enable an exchange of accredited experience and practices.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate my friend Mr Casmarek on his good report and on his generous flexibility in accepting the amendments I tabled to his initial proposal.

Madam President, after expressing my agreement with much of what has been said here and with the text we are voting on tomorrow, I shall express some satisfaction, some concern and some idea of the work we are doing and will continue to do in the European Parliament's Joint Parliamentary Assembly Africa, the Caribbean, the Pacific and the European Union.

My satisfaction goes to the work of Mr Louis Michel, as Co-Chairman of the Assembly, and to our friends in the Commission, with Commissioner Piebalgs at the head, for their interest, their attention and their participation in our tasks, with the simplicity, cordiality and effectiveness that characterize them.

I am concerned, on the other hand, that, absorbed by the rest of the work carried out by the Members of the European Parliament, there is a considerable absence of our representatives in the Joint Assembly, whose work we are here appreciating.
It seems obvious to me that colleagues who are looking at other occupations as a priority should analyse the situation carefully.
I would like to thank him for the importance he attaches to his work in the ACP-EU Assembly, and for leaving his place to other colleagues who may have more time for this activity.
On the other hand, I believe that our Parliament as such should pay more attention to this very work, that the political importance of the Catania Agreement should be understood.
It is the most representative body of North-South cooperation, with almost 80 developing countries, in addition to the 27 or soon to be 28 that make up the European Union.
At a time when global governance must be articulated in a multilateral way, our ACP partners have enormous political potential to articulate joint actions on the international stage.
Our Parliament will also have to pay more attention to the resolutions which our delegates adopt with our ACP colleagues in the Parliamentary Assembly.

We must not continue to pass all kinds of resolutions there with the signature of the European Parliament without even taking note of these texts, at least in the corresponding committees of our House.

The relevant measures must be studied so that, knowing what is debated and approved in the ACP-EU Assembly, the texts that our Parliament approves on the same grounds are coherent and do not, as can sometimes happen, give rise to significant and frankly puzzling discrepancies for our interlocutors.
Mr President, Commissioner Cholos, I am delighted that you are here with us this morning and I hope that you will respond to me a little more seriously and a little more clearly today.

2015 and that the rights to plant vineyards are not liberalised, and he is also in favour of at least maintaining the sugar quota regime until at least 2020.

Valencian farmers do not live on subsidies.

Mr President, Mrs Leuvin's report points well to the fundamental question of joining efforts in the fight against illegal fishing.

The objectives of a common policy on sustainable fisheries, the defence of the marine environment and the promotion of unfair competition are being undermined if this illegal fishing is not fought in a committed manner.
Oceans know no borders, so efforts must be made at both European and international level.

The European Union must therefore be credible in its policies and sanction practices, such as the recently published ones, in which Community-flagged vessels operate illegally in waters protected by conservation measures.
The problem of illegal fishing is not only a question of ships flying the flag of third countries, but also a problem of European operators.

Moreover, we cannot move forward without a strong financial instrument that makes access to public money conditional on the strict implementation of effective controls and the application of all fisheries rules.
I think it is very important to follow closely the implementation of the European protection order.
We are talking about reporting, but these reports must be followed by real protection.
We need money, we can pass good laws, but if we don't provide the countries with the right means, the victims will not trust us and will continue to keep quiet for fear of being attacked again.
Therefore, judges and police officers need to be trained and equipped to do their job well.
That's true justice.
So many victims complain about a law enforcement that doesn't match what they need.
It is therefore necessary that we join forces, that we insist on statistics, to see how this instrument works, which I believe is truly necessary.
I ask the Member States to make an effort to understand and apply this euro order, because we have worked for it and we believe we have made it clear.

Because I have to say that not a single one of the spokesmen who have worked well, even as Mr Schlyter has contributed these notes of humour that were not well done, none of them has had any complaint from any consumer association.

And I also take up and support the Commissioner's words when he says that we must make an effort to win in quality and in quantity. We have to do it, but the Union is a whole, it does not matter where it is produced, and that must also be seen in the fruits and in the juices.

Mr O'Shenar, I read the directive correctly, because it is completely false what you are proposing, because it is not allowed to add aromas from other fruits, it is said that aromas of the same species will be added.

What we could not accept is something that is technically impossible, which is to add the aroma first, necessarily, to favor - we do not know who - to add that aroma of the same fruit that is being squeezed at that moment in the same juice.
Because that, when you store tanks of four million liters and it takes ten thousand liters to extract two liters of aroma, is technically impossible and you should have told it right.
I really invite you, with all kindness, to read the directive carefully, which will surely change your mind.

Mr President, after the climate conferences which have been held since 1995, it can be said that, as they are conceived, they are doomed to failure.

In fact, a planetary agreement is sought and, moreover, it is reached by consensus, an aspiration which is impossible to achieve as a consequence of the very different productive, economic and social structure of the States.
That is why, in the end, they aim to achieve minimum levels, but these are clearly insufficient.
On the other hand, behind climate change lie very deep problems of societies, such as their development and educational models, social differences, poverty, etc., if they all want to be taken away.

At these summits, the difficulties in reaching these agreements will increase, especially if, as is the case, they become large fairs, large international exhibitions with thousands and thousands of participants.
The European Union must keep its environmental flags flying, which Commissioner Hedegaard has done very well in Durban.
That's why, my congratulations.
These summits, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, would require greater coherence between States, more diplomatic work and less festival exhibition.

to take into account and improve those margins which are causing an increase in non-agricultural costs and, finally, to ensure that producers, Madam President, that all products on the Union market meet the same quality standards.
Mr President, intellectual property infringements look like a game, but they kill the game.

They eliminate equality in the free play of competition so that the most fraudulent player wins, that is, the one who does not respect the rules, the one who does not pay taxes, the one who does not respect the rights of either workers or customers.

The observatory, located in Alicante, where the trademark register is already being successfully managed, will reveal, with figures, truths that do not seem so obvious to everyone.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we know that without young people there is no future and we are also certain that with high youth unemployment rates Europe can be unsustainable.

The reality is that Europe has a youth unemployment rate close to
In my country, Spain, it affects 49 of the young people, many of them trained, prepared and talented, who have been expressing their weariness and weariness due to lack of solutions.

The differences between public and concerted education will serve to stimulate creativity and innovation, thus increasing the entrepreneurial spirit, specialization and mobility of students.

Mr President, in addition to the 80 million poor people we are talking about, there are 43 million more people who have difficulty taking animal proteins twice a week.

It continues to get sharper and this is not exactly the best time for the European Union to make budgetary savings on food aid in the run-up to the next financial perspective.

The agreement signed by the European Parliament extends food aid on the terms requested by this House itself, but at the same time it is a bit of a resignation in the face of the blockade that has been maintained for several months by some Member States in the Council.

The European Parliament should not stand idly by in the face of such an important humanitarian issue.
We should not allow things to remain as they are, so we should take advantage of the negotiations on the next financial perspective period to express our opinion.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers has not yet taken a decision on this matter and that it has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
