Mr President, the regulation we are debating today is not perfect, it cannot solve the problems of a sector on its own, with structural problems and also because of the economic context we are experiencing with current problems.
But this regulation, without being perfect, is a step forward, decisive and in the right direction.

Because if we have all recently realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this board, where, in addition, we are playing with people's food safety, all the elements of regulation that we could and of protection for our producers.

It was very necessary that we allow the compulsory nature of contracts with a minimum deadline and with a maximum volume, at least as a defence instrument, because, of course, our producers do not start with the same negotiating strength in front of distributors, intermediaries or collectors.
There's a lot of work to be done.
We must improve safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must strive to put the value chain sector even more at the heart of our policies, to ensure that there is no allocation of quotas, especially in certain areas, or to promote quality policies.

But without a doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended its labour law, the most basic of all, which is to be able to live with dignity from the income of its work.
Mr Orbán has rightly pointed out the disastrous consequences of the approval of this agreement.
Because this agreement, which extends the quotas for certain horticultural products when the figures in the present agreement are not respected, is completely meaningless.

It should be recalled that the Spanish Federation of Producers and Exporters of Fruits and Vegetables denounced to the Committee on Petitions of this Parliament the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan for a price below that set in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described put the European farmer in a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must respect strict quality, environmental and social standards which are not always respected by our Moroccan partners.
In conclusion, I would like to mention the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must have an impact precisely on the local population.
It also constitutes an area over which the UN does not recognise the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, we must ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favour of an agreement with Morocco, in favour of an agreement which establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices, an agreement which fights against dumping, which does not exploit the Moroccan farmer and, above all, which dignifies our European farmers.
It is certainly not this agreement.

Last year, the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions asked the European Commission to amend the rules on the entry prices of fruits and vegetables in the Union, which is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same petition was collected in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France and Italy.

This fraud is being solved by amending the regulation governing the application of the common organisation of the agricultural market, because the alignment of the customs code does not solve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years now, within the People's Party, I have advocated the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union has the necessary instruments to guarantee compliance with the agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must guarantee control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the entry price regime in force prevents national customs authorities from making a correct traceability of the prices declared by importers in order to verify that there are no irregularities.

They modify the regulation on the application of the GMO to agricultural products and we will have solved part of the problem, because otherwise the legal gap in European legislation prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
Again, ladies and gentlemen, the debate on a summit.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, trying to create an expectation that is smaller every day.
They are no longer credible because they do not contribute to solving the crisis.
Summits at which the same agreements are repeated over and over again.

It should be known that as long as political union is not advanced and this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission are not strengthened, the summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In telegraphic form, two ideas: the first is the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfilment of duties are the
The second is to authorise immediately the use of unfunded structural funds.
These amounts can loosely combat the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, I would like to pay tribute to all women in the European Parliament today, who, despite the fact that we have come a long way since that March 1911, when women took to the streets to ask for votes and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still far away.
Today women can work without having to ask permission from anyone, but in many cases they still charge less than men for a similar job, which is unacceptable.
There is also a need to remember women in the rural world whose work is ignored.
I think another uncomfortable reality, but one that needs to be continued to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there has already been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats of those who believe they have the right to use physical or psychological violence against them.
It's time to say enough and say it loud and clear.
Madam President, I reiterate my commitment to the European Victim Protection Order and to the Victims Directive, which the Commission has presented and which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
Mr President, we also have to say - and I would like to remind you - that motherhood is still an obstacle to women's progress, and I think it is a trend that needs to be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and, with the help of many women and more and more men, we must move forward on the path of equality, of opportunities, of rights and also of duties.
We've come a long way, but there's still a lot to do.
I have to admit that I don't believe in quotas at all and in a deep way, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree with you.

I would like to ask many of my colleagues and, of course, Mrs Reding to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women can regain the place they deserve, and with that you can count on my help.

Mr President, in a time of economic crisis and budget cuts which are affecting public health so much and in which, as in the case of the community in which I live, research centres such as Prince Felipe's, which specialises in diabetes, are left without funds, this resolution comes better than ever.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that states that have to increase research, even with stem cells, that have to coordinate their results to optimise them, that have to establish healthy eating and living habits programmes.

In short, we have to put people's health above everything else, and in this case to investigate, coordinate and make national programmes coordinated by the Commission and asking for results on diabetes is to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and to guarantee their own life.

If we spend more money on this, some will be a little more in charge, but I am sure that those who have problems now will have a better quality of life and we will be, as States, as the Council and as the Commission, fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to take care of the health of our citizens.
Mr President, of the many issues raised by this debate, I would like to highlight that of the market for emission rights, a market which was certainly born with defects.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, that is, it is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all the green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, emissions increases are being encouraged.
The financing of important projects, such as energy efficiency projects or carbon storage plants, will be jeopardised.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and Parliament, to conjure it.
Mr President, there are few asylum seekers permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun with the experience.
The cases are, however, of urgent need.
MEPs have thus verified it on the ground, on a trip to Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria, as well as the news that immediately reached us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our rapporteur, the brave Ruiz Tavares, there are many good parliamentarians, but few as tenacious as Ruiz.
Mr Tavares has fought for the European Parliament to retain the new powers it gained after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the constant work that UNHCR has carried out, without which success would not have been possible either.
Mr President, Mr Juncker, Mr Juncker, Mr Juncker, we have all been made aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, thank you very much, Commissioner, and I hope that we will also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of putting forward the asylum package next month.

The European social model, which we so much boast about, is not only rooted in our pension systems, education or healthcare, but also in a way of understanding the balance between entrepreneur and worker within companies.

The labour reform adopted by the Spanish Government without dialogue and without consensus breaks with this social model and takes us away from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of the quality of employment.
Labour reform alone does not create jobs, economic growth does.
What a labour law does is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, where 80 per cent of workers will be left unprotected because they are not subject to collective agreements, where they can be fired because of a drop in corporate income.
What is clear is that workers will enter the labour market with greater precariousness, will remain in the labour market with more fear and will leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and which is committed to the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to the conditions of the workers, deserves a general strike, such as the one called for tomorrow in Spain in defence of this social model.

Mr President, Mr Barroso, go ahead and let the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party think it is right and endorse the two packages it has presented today, both the labour package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which have a lot to do with the coherence of its approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times and that the events of each day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
The focus has inevitably been on Spain again.
And unjustifiably alarms have been sounded in the markets, partly encouraged by statements, in my view, Mr President, that are inappropriate.
One is in the context of important elections, in which both contenders cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, in order to divert attention from its own problems, it also deals with us with little political delicacy.
Today, some here have not been as finesse as the Italians would say, and there has been some lack of political delicacy.
Ladies and gentlemen, the situation of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country and with total capacity to face its debts.
The Spanish debt remains below the average of the European Union and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Mr Svoloda, Mr Rajoy has never said that he could not meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He has said the opposite, that he is willing to meet each and every one of those objectives, and he reiterates this every day.

The Spanish Government, in the few months it has been in charge of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, from yesterday, the IMF itself confesses, are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish Government today.
Other measures we have adopted are the general state budgets for 2012, which, in our view, will ensure that the deficit target is met this year, the Organic Budgetary Stability Act, this month

It will also introduce a reform of education and health, which will mean an adjustment of EUR 1 billion. e reform of the financial sector will undoubtedly also contribute to the fact that financial institutions will have to provide more than EUR 50 billion
In short, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and by the Commission, and what we are asking for is accountability for all.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves together and Spain with all, without any doubt, and it does not contribute in any way to criticism of one or the other, or we are all countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and to the new economy, or it will be difficult, of course, to move forward in the terms proposed by the Commission.
Now I'm leaving. Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the protagonist?
I think it's okay, I wouldn't have any inconvenience.
But Mr Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the legacy received by the Spanish Socialist, Communist and Green Left, which has left the worst legacy that any government has ever left, when they received the best legacy that any government has ever had.
Mr President, this morning I read in an important German newspaper that Spain and Argentina are in a conflict over an oil company.
This is just the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina and, beyond that, with that great European value which is legal certainty and its respect for international trade relations.

The European institutions have magnificent lawyers who can find the appropriate instruments in Community law, whether original or derivative, to neutralize the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of public law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union in the eyes of its citizens is at stake at the moment.

Mr President, we in the Committee on Agriculture share the ultimate objective of this directive, which is to try to guide the composition of our energy mix from taxation, but we are faced with a very complex debate and a very difficult one.

We are full of edges in the economic, in the social and also in the environmental area, in which it is important to maintain those balances that make us move forward more in the environmental area, yes, but that also do not harm us in the economic area and that do not create greater social crises than we are already experiencing.
This is the case with agriculture.

As you all know, energy costs are increasingly a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural farms, at a time when we are also in a debate in which the crises in the commodity markets are combined with a perspective of aid and health and environmental requirements that reduce margins of profitability.
That is why we have asked for two things in the first place.

The first is the maintenance of zero-type deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and implementation of energy efficiency and energy saving strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
In other words, a more demanding environmental policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable in a time of change and uncertainty.
We are experiencing a great controversy which has as essential references the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you hear the noise that is being formed, it would seem that the idea of growth was a bright invention of these days.
Nothing further from reality.
In Europe, the Stability and Growth Pact has been in force since 1997.

That is why a large part of the policies pursued by the European institutions, such as those on regional cohesion and research, are policies aimed at growth and aimed at the development and well-being of citizens.

So I am addressing the Commission and the Members of this Parliament who are most likely to be heard, no complex on our part when it comes to being in this debate, which we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the non-members.
Madam President, let me first of all thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their help in this report, which has made this report much stronger.

We all know that the 20th anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which must be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.
In these 20 years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth and law that generates dynamism.
Transparency, the basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Barnier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework for the protection and training of consumers, and in particular vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This forces us to treat the problem of vulnerability from a transversal analysis that takes into account the different needs, capabilities and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
As an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability is precisely due to their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
the information they receive or the options available to them or their ignorance of the existing claims and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to solve the deficiencies, i.e. the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

The financial sector, whose complexity implies that any consumer can become vulnerable in the power of the market, is a sector that is not only the source of information, but also a source of information.

It therefore calls on the financial services industry to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, accurate information, with a wealth of clear explanations and using direct language on the nature of the products and services it offers.

I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report, and I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, and I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report.

where the lack of transparency in some cases causes an additional difficulty for consumers, for example in the energy sector in determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may find difficulties in accessing the mechanisms
existing ones.
That is why we are asking the Commission and the Member States and allow me to make a call to the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr Gallardon, so that rights do not go backwards.
And it goes in the opposite direction of the course of these difficult times to put intelligence and good government in favor of an alternative resolution of consumer litigation.
Finally, to conclude that any of us are susceptible to becoming vulnerable consumers.
Mr President, Commissioner, the truth is that I have a feeling of despair, almost of frustration, which I must share with someone.
I'm not going to let you do it this afternoon.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had recently in this House on the situation of youth unemployment throughout Europe, and debate after debate, while the youth unemployment rates in some Member States are skyrocketing, we are already close to
While many of them are already left without any kind of social coverage or unemployment, while all this is happening, while we are moving from a situation that is worrying to one that is worrying.

The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this House, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were an analyst, and not as the real government of the Union, which is what it is and what we need.

Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities, governing is about setting priorities, taking the initiative, in addition, with the aim of achieving some end, some objective, and, in addition, the Commission is not doing it.
Governance is not just about restructuring funds, not even announcing them to wash your face in public, but about raising an ambitious, lasting and fast strategy to end youth unemployment.

To govern is not to resign yourself to a youth unemployment rate of over 20 and be satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous in the face of the situation, in the face of the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

Governments must not give in to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other Council Member States who are trying to convince us that we will only get out of this financial crisis, this new wave of recession by renouncing wages, labour rights or compensation, that we can only have a future of precariousness as a generation.

Because if this were true, Commissioner, that only with precariousness do we gain competitiveness and that only by being more precarious will we be able to be more competitive, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country and it is not.
It is Sweden, it is Finland and it is Denmark which are characterised by a model of model relations and also by a model of labour guarantee rights.
Mr President, employment is much more than a right of citizenship, it is an instrument of linking with the system, it is an instrument of social integration.

And therefore, the more unemployment, the greater political disenchantment, and that is why, Commissioner, it does not serve me that you talk about competition issues in order not to do anything about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when the Treaties have had to be interpreted in a lax way in order to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, they have done so, and when the Treaties have had to be reformed in order to meet or satisfy the delusions of some Member State on austerity, we have also done so.
So, what is it that I want to tell you?
There is, for example, the Youth Employment Guarantee, which does not need to be explained.

Fight for an increase in the budget, use the European Social Fund as an instrument if necessary, design a co-financed and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that will help those with the most unemployment, put more pressure on the countries with the worst social conditions to change this policy even more, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is doing badly.
Then will he think, like me, that what is lacking is not whose competence it is, because for the whole of the citizens, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I thank the INTA Committee for the work it has done, the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs.

In general terms, we are faced with a good regulation of the G+ necessary, in particular in some actions to control the rules for the import of textile products which could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, from 2014, of certain countries that are classified as high-middle-income countries, such as Latin America.
Because what about these middle-income countries, which have little diversified exports?
Why not introduce a diversification criterion for exports?
Because in this, two speeds could be produced, countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

I therefore believe that we must support a transitional period and that amendments will be tabled with this transitional period in order to adapt these countries to this situation and to give them the opportunity to open negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr President, I already supported Mrs Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo with other Members of Parliament, and I have indeed found that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest will to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, needs to believe also in its state and in its government, and that is not going to be possible with electoral support or with external support alone.
They also need a demand to fight corruption and break the indecent paradox that it means living in poverty in one of the richest countries in the world in resources.

And it must be said and denounced that part of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals who, from Europe or other continents or other States, are capable of participating in corruption without importing them, encouraging the struggles for those resources to win the favor of those who run some territories.

That is why, Mrs Ashton, although it is not your absolute competence, I do say that a greater demand for traceability and transparency on the part of European multinationals and others from other continents who collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the help we can give them at the electoral and technical level.
Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have done.

Ladies and gentlemen, we are now debating Package 2, after having adopted Package 6, after almost all the Heads of State or Government have agreed on two international treaties outside the ordinary legislative procedure.

The European Union, after many other European standards have created more Community authorities for banking supervision, stock exchange supervision, insurance supervision, for the risks of the economic system.
the deployment of texts and more texts, reports, proposals addressing new criteria for economic assessment, new procedures, new procedures.
We must not stop and apply what we have already approved.
In the face of the instability of the European continent, the exact opposite is needed: stability and legal certainty.
We don't need a bunch of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I'm dreaming.
The situation of the rescue is very worrying.
The whole truth is not told to the Spanish citizens with the new debt, which, by endorsing private debt, the Spanish Government and the State assume as public debt.
The Spanish Government has requested aid which it had previously said it would not want and it presents it ridiculously as a triumph, as a colleague has already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph but failure with Banquo and so on.

I insist that there is no more correct policy for Europe than that sponsored by the French Government, behind which parliamentary ranks must be closed, because we will not get out of debt without harmonious growth for all and for the whole.

Supervision, as called for in both reports, of course, all the supervision that is necessary, but also essential, simultaneous, anti-speculative growth, as also alluded to in some of the measures in both reports and in other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency, also balance, as my colleague, Mr Sánchez Presedo, said earlier.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls around the world, 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.
An unbearable figure for those who stop to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, religious reasons, all of which are false.

The truth is that ablation, preferably in girls as young as 14 and even as young as one year old, can lead to death by hemorrhagic collapse and, in the best of cases, cause and bring about strong psychological consequences due to trauma.
From Europe we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which violates the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
This is about abuse, cruelty and torture of girls, and this denigrating treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the preventive mechanisms available in our legal system, and I encourage our judges to act to prevent genital mutilation.
We have girls in Europe, punishing those who do it, that the law in Europe speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to be actively involved in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us are not going to stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons why we approved the milk package was precisely to adapt the sector to a milk quota-free market in 2015.

But it is also true that as this date of liberalisation approaches, the uncertainty in the sector increases because we do not see a clear exit strategy, and the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection on the decision we are afraid of also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty in the sector about the real effects of the milk package and about

We will have had time to make a serious assessment of them and also for reasons such as the uncertainty about where the common agricultural policy is going and especially its budget, that is, about the part of the income that does not come from the markets and affects our producers.

So what we are asking you, Commissioner, is to transfer it to Mr Choloz, so that we do not make a patchwork policy of dismantling our protection systems without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is prepared to postpone the end of the quota until 2015 until a date that gives security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on the regulatory mechanisms, because the markets are still more unfair and the producers are increasingly helpless.
Mr President, many Members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have said that this is a yes or no agreement.
We Members of this Parliament also have a responsibility for yes or no.
And we say no because this agreement produces confusion, as is obvious.
Intellectual property rights and the rights of Internet users are not clarified.
Internet users, are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
I see.
Yes, it is an ACTA solution.

No, there is no solution, because there are two issues to be addressed. It is not a legal issue, but two political issues. One is determination in the fight against counterfeiting and the other is determination in the fight against counterfeiting.
Piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly asked for from the Socialist Group, we are asking for again.
It's your chance.
Don't turn your back on society, because tomorrow it's going to collapse and there's no way out.
If they improve, sometimes it is necessary to intensify the chaos.
The feeling of impotence was of such a magnitude that Europe had to react, and it has done so for the good of all, because the great winner of this last summit has been the euro.
And with this triumph, the hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, ladies and gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as long-term measures to address the Union's shortcomings.
In this case, the immediate was essential to continue working for the important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as important as enabling the European Stability Mechanism to recapitalise banks directly, which will break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish Government.
In addition, it will serve to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their public deficit and reform commitments.
These were decisions necessary to ensure financial stability, which must be the European Union's top priority in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and put sticks in the way.
I have already said it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reformist agenda of Spanish democracy, including a profound labour reform.
In addition, it is carrying out a financial reform based on total transparency, all of which demonstrates its commitment to fiscal consolidation and compliance with the deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr President, the Community first and then the European Union has always been not only to overcome crises, but to emerge strengthened from them.
I'm glad we got it done once again.
We, ladies and gentlemen, have focused all our attention on the banks, which we have repeatedly heard say are the blood of the social body.
It is likely that this image is correct, but let us bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and the joints of this social body, which we call Europe, are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructure.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the House, to mobilise private financing and, in your case, public financing.
It is also an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, backed by the European institutions, specifically intended for these purposes and open to any investor.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on their work and also the Commission on its clear impetus to these projects.

Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, in welcoming the new Presidency, I am a veteran militant of the disappeared non-aligned movement that led your country and that fervently desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and gentlemen, we had to take the opportunity for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the claims of the Commission and my colleague the rapporteur are very positive and must be supported by the unanimity he had in our committee.
The agility and good functioning of the Court are basic, which I question with the new, now delayed, patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the rapporteur on the reform of the Court.

Mr President, Commissioner Reding, my country has been going backwards too much since the arrival of the People's Party in government, repeatedly and continuously trying to go backwards in consolidated rights, such as covering up the little that displeases, among others, consumer organizations.
The threat to FACUA, undermining, among other things, Articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution by Mrs Mato's Ministry, is a dangerous attack.

Not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, basic principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore call for the correction of Mr Rajoy's Government in the face of the attempt to make Facua illegal and I call on the Commission to ensure the protection of the
the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction in the rights and functions of consumer associations which the current Government of Spain intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to highlight the great work of Mrs McAvan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs in bringing this report to fruition.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but, as has been said, recent events of all known and demonstrated that there was a certain
There was a gap that needed to be corrected so that it would not happen again and specific points of surveillance and safety of medicines once marketed had to be strengthened.
That is why, as has been said, from now on, holders of a marketing authorisation for a medicinal product which they do not renew, withdraw or request for withdrawal or suspend will have to:
It is the obligation to state the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or suspension of authorisation of a medicinal product.
This is a great achievement in terms of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorisation from trying to hide the real reasons for his decision.
In addition, if any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all Member States concerned, where this medicine is marketed, should be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without overburdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.

The second important modification that has been achieved is that all authorised products that are subject to a post-authorisation safety study are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Finally, we cannot forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role and that is why this House must approve this proposal.
Mr President, the agreement reached by Parliament and the Council reflects what the Member States concerned unanimously adopted in the WTO.
These seas are in a worrying state in terms of acidification.
In addition, its regenerative capacity is very limited.
The required fuels are going to be more expensive and that is why economic aid is foreseen for entrepreneurs, which is very reasonable.
But some colleagues have tried to ensure that the requirements for new fuels also apply to all the seas of the European Union.

We would find ourselves in the paradox that an environmental problem in some countries of the Union wants to be solved by creating a first-class economic problem in the Mediterranean which does not have that problem, but which has another type of environmental problem whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The treaty is very clear.
We must protect sensitive areas.
But not all areas are equally sensitive.

Mr President, I would like to thank again all those who have made it possible for this directive to become a reality, the secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those whom I have forgotten and all the colleagues who have been with us.
I want to tell the victims, all of them, absolutely all of them, without any difference, that for us, they and their families have a face, they have a name, they are real and precisely in their name.

We will work so that this directive not only does not remain on wet paper, but that, with the commitment and help of Commissioner Reding, which I do not doubt at all, it has a rapid and effective implementation, which is what we all hope for.
I am a citizen.

I think there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and still want their own directive, but I will tell you that the directive we are voting on tomorrow does not forget any victims and therefore does not forget them either.
And I am sure that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long to the victims.
When they ask me, when they ask me in my country what you do in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favour of the victims.
And that work, personally, honors me deeply and gives me a lot of strength to keep working.

I am sure that with the support and commitment not only of those who work here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will succeed, among all of us and also with that of His Excellency, in bringing the victims out of this unjust oblivion.

Mr President, Mr Turmes has done an admirable job because it took the courage of this rapporteur, who has been able to neutralize the many and skillfully devised obstacles, to put forward a standard like this.
It has been worth it, because efficiency in the use of energy and its savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We must welcome important measures such as the requirement to renovate public buildings, the imposition of a percentage of accumulated energy savings on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits on large private companies.
Now, the work of Turmes and the rest of the rapporteurs will be of no use if it is not accompanied by decisive action by the Member States.
This action must in turn be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives by the regions, municipalities and European citizens.
I would like to highlight the participation of the latter.
At the moment, what is being noticed is a lot of frivolity between the authorities and the citizens.
Do we not see, ladies and gentlemen, in the harsh European winter, people sitting on heated street terraces?
Friend Turness, we must not spare any effort to save energy.
We must congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Aira García, on the work she has done and congratulate her on the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It's a pity that tonight the Council won't be with us.
Mr President, the new quality scheme for agricultural products means simplifying the system and streamlining existing authorisation procedures, and that is good news.

It is also a good achievement that the obligation to use the Community logo for protected designations of origin and geographical indications has been included, because this improves the visibility of European productions.
It also seems to me that it is remarkable that the provisions on the protection of quality claims in bilateral agreements with third countries are strengthened and that a legal basis is created for
I would like to defend the European Union's logo in those third countries, because I sincerely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be an indispensable objective.

It is a pity that during the negotiations this package has been left a little unfinished and it is a pity, I say again, that the Council is not here to hear it, because the original quality package that was proposed

The Commission has been a little forgetful of the trade standards and the management of supply by the quality origin denominations, which are excluded from the agreement and, as I say, leave it a little empty.
I think we must regret the Council's failure to listen to Parliament's positions on these two issues, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by the denominations of origin should have been defended and will certainly be defended in the WTO.

Mr President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia and Peru is an important agreement and the safeguard clause, what it tries to do, and with the amendments we have tabled, is to make it easy, agile and guaranteed.

We have tabled amendments to protect European production in accordance with the Treaties and we have established safety mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the Agreement is concluded.
The protection of outermost areas is necessary because they are not diversified crops, because of the economic factor, because it affects a large number of them.
More than 10 direct and 35 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely punished by unemployment and by its specificity.
For example, the Canary Islands banana has a great specificity in agriculture, culture and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary where we are going to establish the agreement, in Central America, Colombia and Peru, because trade is fundamental to development and development is labour rights, sustainability and benefits for the producer.

Mr President, the rapporteur's work is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can warn.
We have forgotten what Pufendorf already taught that general laws must be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who enact it must use as much clarity as possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language should be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric rhetoric, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowing, because it creates a malignant network where traps nest and arbitrariness settles.
We deal with very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our duty to make them accessible to citizens in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common for even the very professionals in law, judges, lawyers, to despair at our texts.
Good prose, ladies and gentlemen, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way of showing his respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I just spent the little time I had insulting, disqualifying from the most absolute ignorance.
You know the Spanish Constitution.

Because what Vice-President Vidal Cuadrás has said is neither more nor less than what is said in the Spanish Constitution, the rest are singular personal appreciations that are absolutely irrelevant and that I can respect but that I despise.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an old principle which has passed from the legal to the political sphere, and that is the pacta sunt servanda, that is to say, agreements are to be fulfilled.
By this I mean the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to solve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased and these have welcomed positively decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council, which was held last week, contains undeniable positive aspects.
The A27 agreement for the launch of the banking supervisor is also positive.
But they will allow him to make a critical judgment with the biased interpretations that have been unilaterally made of it.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations which may denature the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy, as we do not welcome the fact that matters which were not even dealt with are reported as agreements.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism which should cover all financial institutions.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are unquestionable: increased competition, increased supply of products and services.
services, job creation, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, which are still insufficient and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully benefiting from the advantages of the single market.
A year and a half ago we celebrated the presentation of the Twelve Priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in its communication last week.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis forces us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr President, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the rest of the colleagues who have worked very adequately on this reform.

The financial crisis has increased due to the existence of complex and strange negotiable values linked to derivatives and negotiations outside the official markets, all in the hope of achieving high profitability very quickly.
It is necessary to attract financial operations to a transparent market in order to ensure good price formation and competition for negotiable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information offered is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge in order to give free consent to the risks they take.
Transparency is useless as a great flash of light if the confusion in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
I like Mrs Thyssen's report because I believe that all that it takes to strengthen this Parliament's role and authority in the political debate is to go in the right direction.
Too often we hear the European institutions accused of being of poor democratic quality.
This is a light-hearted statement, which is not the occasion to enter into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament has the same legitimacy as any national parliament and it is even likely that, with respect to some, it will be governed by more transparent rules and, moreover, will allow its Members greater freedom.
That is why all economic measures must pass through the filter that this Parliament represents before its final approval and then, when examining its implementation and its results.
the group of experts appointed to verify in the States the compliance with the conditions imposed by the Community authorities and the representatives of the Member States;
The two stability mechanisms must be presented in this House so that Members can have access to comprehensive information and first-hand information.
Mr President, 5.3 of the working population works in the automotive sector.
The numbers speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, combined with the business strategy, makes it possible, in general terms, to outsource and restructure companies.
There is a crisis of overcapacity which currently affects ten assembly plants and potentially 100 workers.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision, usually a short-term vision in which the main element is to gain competitiveness on the basis of labour adjustments.

I have to tell you that on the very day that Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, it was announced to the company in Valencia, Ford, that its production was going to be transferred to Germany, in the same business statement.

We therefore believe that it is a general problem of Europe, we believe that it is essential to create a legal framework at European level that anticipates change and underlines the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr President, we are debating today four reports which represent a revitalisation of our common security and defence policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defence have a clear European dimension, in the face of the Eurosceptic minority sectors which are also campaigning in this House.
Mr Danjean's report, to which I would like to thank him for his spirit of seeking consensus during its preparation, contains important contributions from the Socialist Group.
Among other things, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect or the concept of human security.
We would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European defence strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common security and defence policy is also of interest to our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that are taking on important dimensions for our global security.
It is the report on cybersecurity and cybersecurity, which we are also debating today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which Member States are being forced to cut their defence budgets, it is when European projects are most needed.
That is why it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being questioned today.
I conclude by saying that we can relaunch European security and defence and do so with President von der Leyen's project for the Council in December 2013.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defence of the general interests defended by the Commission and Parliament is clashing with the national selfishness that is at work in the Council.
Since the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable to achieve a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is unacceptable to our judgment.
A cut of 75 million euros on the already inevitably scarce proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And not only that, the new direct link to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain has pointed out since the beginning of the work.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to discuss a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making tried and tested efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity and create jobs.
And with this budget you don't get anywhere, rather it constitutes a missile on the floating line.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with many fewer resources, and above all if what is there is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union which would mean the smooth and plain disappearance of growth possibilities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, to whom we must thank for its commitment to indicate a different route.

And on this point, on the need for the Union, on the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cadiz on the interpretation of the Treaties for a supposed secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State is separated as an independent State, it is considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr Vice-President, in the absence of the President, that this can be collected and that this safe and constant doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
